title: five new years resolutions for labours new leader to save the countrys opposition
story: The post-Christmas choice is dire. Which will it be  The acidic lime-barrel, the chewy coconut caramel or the tooth-shattering walnut swirl Labour Party members face that sort of dilemma this week.The contest to be their next leader will begin properly today when MPsto Westminster. Defeat in last month’s ­General Election has left the party’s ranks depleted.The choice of candidates is hardly appetising.If you were talking about Quality Street, you’d say they’re all a bit nutty.Will it be wonkish Sir Keir Starmer, a legal oddball who never blinks, or will it be ­prolier-than-thou Jess Phillips, veering all over the political piste like Austrian ski legend Franz Klammer after lunch Could it be Lady Wobbles  I talk, naturally, of Emily Thornberry, who may or may not be the lovechild of Hattie Jacques and Boris Yeltsin.Her snobbery about White Van Man will probably knock la-di-dah Emily out of the running, although she is probably the one the Tories fear most.What about tough guy Clive Lewis, an unknown fashion dude from East Anglia whose only criticism of Jeremy Corbyn is that he wasn’t really left-wing enough Wigan lass Lisa Nandy — so earnest she looks asshe could burst into tears at any moment — is also in the contest. Then there is Rebecca Long-Bailey, she of the Mrs Merton spectacles, fanciedby Corbyn’s old Marxist sidekick John McDonnell.Long-Bailey is untested. But so are the others. I was going to shock you by noting that Thornberry, having once been a ministerial aide, is the only candidate to have had a snf of Whitehall experience.Then I realised that she is the only one of them to have actually sat on the governing side in the House of Commons.Nandy became an MP in , when Labour left office.The rest entered the Commons only in .OK, let’s look on the bright side. They should all have a certain novelty value.So how come they feel so unexciting  It’s because they represent old ideas.Tony Blair is nowadays a discredited figure but when he was leader of the Opposition in the s, he did something shrewd.He wrenched his party into the modern era by producing a pledge card with five basic promises. They helped him win a landslide in the  General Election.Blair’s five pledges reflected the electorate’s priorities: Smaller class sizes for primary schools, quicker punishment of young offenders, shorter NHS waiting times, getting younger people off benefits by using a windfall tax on privatised utilities, and a promise not to raise income tax.Blair grasped how Labour was seen by the voters. His pledge card helped address those worries. The policies themselves were only part of the trick. Equally important was the idea that Blair’s Labour was prepared to listen.A quarter of a century on, the next Labour leader should repeat Blair’s trick and be honest about how the party is seen.Here are five basic philosophical pledges that might help to address the problem.PLEDGE : Saving is a virtue. One reason Jeremy Corbyn bombed in last month’s election was that his spending plans were seen as madly extravagant. Voters may not like government “austerity” but they aren’t mugs. They know state spending has to be paid for.If you are a government or an inidual, you can’t live for ever on the never-never.It’s time Labour reacquainted itself with prudence.PLEDGE : Patriotism is honourable. Wouldn’t it be amazing to hear a Labour leader say this Yet since the decline of the British Empire, the Left has regarded patriotism as a dirty word. This is electorally crazy.Patriotism is merely an expression of civic pride, of communal values channelled into the identity of the democratic nation state and its Queen.Working-class former Labour voters love American patriotism .They applaud the Aussies and South Africans when they wave their flags.What is so wrong with being proud of Britain PLEDGE : Stable families strengthen us all.I’m not making a point about marital infidelities — MPs are the last people who should preach about sex! — but Labour’s promotion of metropolitan lestyles has created an idea it disapproves of “normal” family set-ups.Add to that its reluctance to give families tax breaks and its strange cultural suspicion of adoption. Former Labour seats are often areas with the strongest notion of traditional family solidarity.A wise leadership candidate would acknowledge that.PLEDGE : Brexit is irreversible. Please. This matter has been settled.And yet that fool Jess Phillips is hinting that she wants us to rejoin the EU. Electoral suicide.PLEDGE : No more jobsworths. Bigger than everything  is the suspicion that officialdom is an ass.The British people are wonderfully tolerant but they are driven mad by petty regulation — particularly when it comes to minority grievances.“Jobsworths” who say that ignoring daft political-correctness is “more than my job’s worth” are the bane of Britain.Who is more intolerant: A provincial baker who hesitates to ice a wedding cake for a gay couple, or the gay couple who take that baker to the High Court to prove a point We all know whose side Labour politicians would have been on.A would-be Labour leader who cheerfully made these pledges would be a Labour leader who could connect with the electoral mainstream.But will any of them do so  Don’t hold your breath.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ricky gervais golden globes speech hollywood
story: We salute Ricky Gervais. He’s been rude to the world’s biggest stars before. Never has he hit the nail on the head like that or with such venom.For too long, politically correct movie actors and musicians have lectured the little people on how to live better lives, lives more like theirs. They tell us to cut back — as they fly around the globe in private jets and live in multiple mansions with monstrous carbon footprints.They leap aboard every soul-sappingly tedious and vacuously “woke” bandwagon and instruct us to do the same.They tell us how to vote — always noisily and cluelessly backing the left, safe in the knowledge no forced redistribution could ever really dent their vast wealth.At last a fellow multi-millionaire actor and comic has told them to shut up. That they’re “in no position to lecture the public about anything”. That they “know nothing about the real world”.Ordinary people ARE sick of these ill-informed egomaniacs. That’s why celebrity endorsements never help Labour here — or the Democrats in the US.We doubt that any of these Golden Globetrotters will have the self-awareness or humility to wind their necks in.But we’re proud that as millions watched, cheering, a plain-talking Brit burst the celebs’ bubble.Every word was bang on their money.WE have our fingers crossed for the Cyprus gang-rape teenager as she learns her fate today.She may yet be freed with a presidential pardon. If not, the already grave doubts about the country’s justice ­system will deepen.And our Foreign Secretary will have every justication in warning Brits about the safety of its resorts like Ayia Napa.It is increasingly obvious this young woman was shamefully treated, by the men involved, by police and by the judge.President Nicos Anastasiades must end this madness.BREXITERS have won another battle: The Government will launch parallel trade talks with the US and EU next month. Excellent.It’s not just that a little competition should generate some urgency in both. Especially Brussels, whose new Irish trade chief Phil Hogan still foolishly seems to believe — against all the ­evidence — that there is mileage in sneering at ­Britain, Brexit and Boris.It’s also that, when it comes to America, we must strike while the iron is hot.We are top of Donald Trump’s list for a deal. And he likes Boris. But Trump may not win a second term and his replacement could be less keen.Britain cannot afford to delay.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: human ken doll appears on this morning
story: In an emotional interview Roddy Alves, , from Brazil, admitted she had prayed for God to change her as she tried her best to be a male.The Celebrity Big Brother star, dubbed the Human Ken Doll, has spent more than £, on plastic surgery but now admits she always identied more with Barbie rather than her male counterpart.Speaking on This Morning she told Holly and Phil: I have always been in touch with my feminine side.At the age of two I would always play with dolls, I would wear my mothers dresses and shoes and they would try to stop me but then I would cry.But what I remember very clearly is that at the age of five, six and seven I didnt know the dference between a boy and a girl and I only played with barbie dolls.Roddy was born to a Catholic family and went to strict religious boarding school in Brazil.She admitted she spent most of her time socialising with girls which left her a target to be bullied by the boys.She said: Due to my religion being catholic and going to a school like that I always prayed and I prayed for God to change me.After moving to London when she was  she decided she needed to forget her feelings and continue being a man.Thats when she started her plastic surgery journey.She said: I tried my best to be a male I had a fake six pack put in, arms put in but I failed badly because I was never happy.I carried on having those plastic surgeries because actually I wanted to be a woman.After first revealing her hidden identity struggle she told the Mirror she now feels like the real me.She said: “It feels ­amazing to finally tell the world I’m a girl.“I’m known as Ken but inside I’ve always felt like Barbie.”

title: pub regulars served first
story: Last week The Teal Arms, in Stockton-on-Tees, placed a sign on the bar informing drinkers that regular customers would be served before them and to accept it and shut the f*** up.The notice stated that Bob who is a regular, will be served first as the bartender knows him by name and that he drinks here seven days a week, every week.According to the sign, it is Bob and other regulars that keep the bar open and running eleven months of the year.Although, the landlord insists the notice is just a joke, some patrons dont agree.One visitor said: I personally find it unprofessional and quite a disgrace. It clearly doesnt encourage new customers to come in.The sign fully reads: If an old bloke sat at the bar gets served before you do, and the bartender knows him by name and even seems to know what hes drinking before he orders it, just shut the f*** up.It continues: Thats Bob. Bob drinks here all the time.Bob drinks here seven times a week, every week. Bobs custom pays the bills.Bob and the other regulars keep the pub open eleven months of the year whilst youre having dinner parties and bulk-buying booze from the supermarket.Yes, they get preferential treatment. Accept it and shut the f*** up.But the Teal Arms landlord, who did not wish to be named, told the Gazette Live that locals find it funny.It is believed the notice, which looks to be handmade and printed on white paper, has been secured to the wall, at the end of the bar, near where Bob stands every day.Others say the sign has to be read in context and Bob is served at the same time as everyone  as bartenders know what he is drinking.The Teal Arms told the Sun Online: It was put up as a joke for two local customers called Bob. It was up for three days then the sign was removed.It didn’t cause an issue or offend anybody other than the two people that were looking to discredit us as they were causing problems in our pub on a few dferent occasions and being asked to leave.

title: who stephen clements bbc radio ulster
story: But who was he and how did he die Stephen Clements was a radio host and presenter from Northern Ireland.He joined Radio Ulster in September last year, saying the move was his dream job.He began his career at Citybeat before hosting Q Radios breakfast show from .Stephen was married to Natasha Clements, the pair had two children.Yesterday, Stephen shared a final heartbreaking tweet of his family, with the prayer and love emoji symbols.Stephen co-hosted BBC Northern Irelands Children in Need programme in November .His Q Radio breakfast show was one of the most popular in Northern Ireland.Stephen went on to co-present BBC Northern Ireland TV series Open for Summer, which aired during the Open Golf Championship at Portrush, County Down in .He took the reins at Radio Ulsters mid-morning programme from veteran presenter Sean Coyle in .Stephen and Natasha had two children, Poppy, seven, and Robbie, three.BBC Northern Ireland director Peter Johnston said: “We are sorry to bring you the sad news of the passing of our colleague, Stephen Clements.“Our thoughts are with Stephen’s family, friends and colleagues, at this dficult time.”In a statement from the BBC, the presenters death was described as sudden, but no further details have been revealed.A spokesman for Q Radio posted: We are heartbroken today to learn that our former Q Radio Breakfast show host, colleague and friend Stephen Clements has died suddenly at the age of .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jeremy bamber begs itv postpone drama
story: The convicted murderer, , has maintained his innocence since being caged for the mass killing of five relatives in a remote Essex farmhouse in .But last month his lawyers served a Judicial Review application against the Crown Prosecution Service over claims they refused to disclose key documentation to the defence.It comes after ITV announced they will be showing a six-part series about the killings staring Stephen Graham and Mark Addy that begins tomorrow night.The Sun Online can reveal that Bambers team contacted ITV so they could provide the channel with “brand new forensic reports and fresh evidence”.However, ITV refused to engage and his solicitors were not consulted or asked to assist in any way.Bamber’s supporters now feel they have been “ignored” and say the show will be “based on factually incorrect material”.The Jeremy Bamber Campaign said: “We first became aware of a planned ITV drama about Jeremy’s case in December .“We took immediate steps to offer our assistance by contacting Kim Varvell at Production Company ‘New Pictures’, Commissioning Editor Kevin Lygo at ITV and writer Chris Mrska.“We were willing to provide access to brand new forensic reports, our team of scientists, the case material, fresh evidence, and Jeremy and his legal team.“Our offers were ignored, and we believe therefore, that the drama can only be based on factually incorrect and very out of date material.“Our campaign is not only about proving Jeremy’s innocence, but protecting the memory of his much-loved family who will undoubtedly have their characters dissected and denigrated in order to make sensationalised television.“This will not benefit anyone, least of all Jeremy in his fight for justice, but will simply be a money pot for ITV, reaping in millions of pounds from a family tragedy that is still unresolved.“We need to make it clear that the Jeremy Bamber Campaign, Jeremy, and his legal team, do not endorse this drama.“Mark Newby, Jeremy’s solicitor, has written to ITV requesting that owing to the sensitivity in the current legal approaches that have been made to the High Court that the drama at the very least be postponed.”The lawyer added: “We have written to the producers of the drama series and invited them to postpone the broadcast of this series whilst matters are resolved in the High Court.“We have intimated that we are title: caravans trimingham house caravan park north norfolk
story: Aerial photos show how caravans at Trimingham House Caravan Park, in North Norfolk, are on the edge of danger after the clfside crashed onto the beach on January .The coastguard confirmed that only one of the caravans at the park was being used at the time by a woman and her child, and they were both led to safety.Officials have urged residents to stay away from the beach, which lies about five miles east of Cromer.Tony Garbutt, coastguard sector commander in North Norfolk, said: “There was only one person who was occupying a caravan who was in danger and she was removed safely with her child“We then removed all her belongings to render that safe and then we went about making the site safe so we disconnected utilities and there are about six caravans that really need to be pulled back from the clf over the next two to three days.”The landslide was caused by a build up of water in the clf after heavy rain last month, the coastguards said.Mr Garbutt said the water seeps into the sandy earth making the the clf unstable before gravity takes over.People have now been warned to steer clear of the beach in case more of the clf falls over the next few weeks.Mr Garbutt said: The clf as it is at the moment is still unstable so there is still movement there and the next two to three days will tell usthere is going to be any further movement.“Some of the clf that has fallen is still moving down the side of the clf. The biggest problem is the soil which has been deposited on the beach is made up of sand and a lot of silt and when you mix that with water that becomes very sticky.“So the safety message to the public would be please don’t clamber all over it as you can get yourself into danger.”It is the second landslip along the stretch of coast in a month.Trimingham House Caravan Park is spread over  acres and has  static caravans and holiday homes.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: jamie east running changes lives
story: But we humans are highly talented at only seeing what we want to.Running is brilliant, yet viewed in the same light as a tax bill we’re pretending isn’t due. Just because you ignore it, it doesn’t mean it no longer exists.Now research shows that going for regular runs could add years to your le.Running reverses the effects of ageing on your blood vessels, and even after a few goes runners have lower blood pressure than when they started.I’m about to run my first marathon at the ripe old age of , having built up the habit from a standing start.Here are some other good things running does:Weight will drop off you — I’m three stone lighter after taking it up two years ago. Your sleep cycle improves. Weirdly, you will have more energy. Your mental health will be better. It will spur you on to be healthy in other aspects of le.I get it, though. It’s easy to look at the swathe of runners and balk. Not a single thing about it looks fun.While some jammy gits manage to glide around the streets looking effortless, most of us look sweaty, out of breath and in deep, deep discomfort. Because we are.Most runners hate doing the actual running. Occasionally, on a nice balmy evening, you might forget you are five miles from home and the only way to get there is to keep running. But more often than not, you’re willing it to be over.No, most runners don’t run for the joyful act of running — we run for the sublime, borderline orgasmic feeling of having run.I sobered up more than two years ago, which would never have been a success had I not taken up running.I was a fastidious non-runner. I’d tried it, it was boring and it really, really hurt. But as those with addictive personalities know only too well, you have to swap drink with something. After Robbie Williams gave up cocaine he ensured Colombia still earned a few quid by necking up to  espressos a day.Like all men staring middle age in the face, I’d ignored any form of cardio exercise and instead spent a decade seeking the cliched T-shirt look.Abs that could give you a paper cut, biceps like grapefruits and whole hams for shoulders.All that cardio looked too much like hard work. And besides, you didn’t see Brad Pitt legging it round the park in Fight Club, did you Well as it turns out, the abs didn’t materialise and I just ended up feeling miserable. So when sobriety kicked in and I had a lot more time on my hands, I decided to see what running was about.My first go was an absolute tragedy and I am grateful no one witnessed me running a mere  yards before tripping over my dog. It was awful. I was wheezing and clutching my spare tyre, but I had broken the seal.Five minutes later I felt great. The dopamine and endorphins kicked in and I could have taken on the world, although my hamstrings said otherwise.Those  yards became  the next day and so on until I hit my first milestone — one whole kilometre. I was now officially hooked.Within two months I had completed my first Parkrun. Anyone who feels self-conscious about running should join their local Parkrun, as the sense of community and inclusion is fantastic.I’d shed a stone and felt utterly incredible — and I didn’t stop there. I now run more than  miles every week and in April I will take on my first London Marathon. I’m excited but also utterly terried.If you’re a non-runner, the thought of running is daunting.But trust me, aside from giving up smoking, it will be the most rewarding thing you’ll do for your body and mind. As well as the physical benefits it really, really sorts your head out.No social media, no people chasing work — it’s just you and your thoughts. I’ve had some of my best ideas and made some le-changing decisions running along the side of the Basingstoke canal.Just try it for a week. It’s completely free, unless you’re like me and treat it as an excuse to open up a whole new world of gadgetry.You can do it anywhere at any time you feel like it. And, crucially, you will never regret going for a run, ever.Put on any old pair of trainers, stick the headphones in, listen to a podcast, pick a landmark to run to and just go for it, as slowly as you need to. If it hurts, stop running and walk, then run again for a bit — and so on.This was me two years ago — and now Mo Farah had better be looking over his shoulder in April .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Charlotte McAteer, , thought she had bagged herself a bargain when she found the luxurious fluffy rug on Wish for just £..The rug was advertised much larger onlineBut when the item arrived in a jfy bag, the mum of one found it was just big enough for her baby daughter to stand on.Charlotte, from Salisbury, Wilts, said: I opened it up and it is literally the size of a side plate.Its got these really thin hairs coming off the bottom. title: bbc presenter dress bursts open
story: Points West anchor Liz Beacon, , was drafted in at the last minute to present the evening news and rushed home to grab her new and unworn Zara outfit.But minutes before going live the zip “popped”, leaving the black fitted dress gaping all down her back.Without time to change, her quick-thinking crew pulled it together using metal bulldog clips and gaffer tape - and took a photo to show Liz.Viewers had no idea of the wardrobe mal when they tuned in to watch the live broadcast just  minutes later.Liz, from Bristol, said: I hadnt worn the dress before and it was a bit sticky when I did the zip up, but I just thought that was because the dress is quite a tight style anyway.Never in a million years did I imagine it would burst open half an hour later.”The dress, bought at Cabot Circus shopping centre in Bristol, was a birthday gt from her mother in December.Liz was looking forward to debuting it on the programme because it was dferent to her usual presenting outfits.She managed to stay composed for the entire  minute programme with her dress haphazardly taped and clipped closed behind her.Liz said: We go live on air at .pm and at about .pm I felt this pop and thought, I dont believe this, I think the zip has just gone.I asked the director - another Liz - to come and take a look, and when she saw it, she gasped and said Quick, get me some clips and some gaffer tape.I had no other options. title: labour leadership sir keir starmer storms ahead in first 24 hours
story: The Remainer London MP has shown up rivals Emily Thornberry and Lisa Nandy who have gained very little traction in the first day.As the first stage of the three-month long contest gets off to a roaring start, candidates have hustled to get as many nominations from fellow MPs and MEPs as possible.The nominations opened yesterday and Sir Keir has already secured .Rebecca Long Bailey, seen as the continuity candidate to succeed current leftie leader Jeremy Corbyn, has secured only seven nominations so far.Shadow foreign secretary Emily Thornberry and Wigan MP Lisa Nandy languished on one and two nominations respectively.Meanwhile, Corbynista Clive Lewis failed to secure a single nomination from any of his Labour colleagues.Candidates have until Monday to fight to get to the magic number - Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA leak of more than , New Year Honours recipientsapos private details was left online for more than three hours, the government has admitted. Tory ministers issued an unreserved apology for the blunder and launched an independent review last night after the Cabinet Office initially said the list of addresses was online for about an hour. Sir Elton John, senior police officers and former Director of Public Prosecutions Alison Saunders were all among those who had their details accidentally uploaded to the government website.At the time of the leak between Christmas and New Year, the Cabinet Office told the BBC the data was online for around an hour. Another outlet reported the Cabinet Office had said it was online for  minutes.Last night, however, Cabinet Office minister Oliver Dowden has claried that while a link to the data was removed after  minutes, anyone who had the direct web link could continue to see the data for a further  minutes. That meant the data was only fully removed  minutes after it went online at .pm on Friday  December - despite being spotted by the government at pm. The blunder has been reported to the Information Commissioner which has the power to issue multi-million pound fines. And the Cabinet Office last night launched an independent review of data handling practices in the department - which co-ordinates work between the whole of Whitehall and  Downing Street. This review will focus on process, culture, policy and practice within the Department, Mr Dowden said. It will establish whether appropriate controls are in place around the storage, sharing and deletion of personal data, including learning lessons from this case. More information on this review will be published shortly. Changes have already been made to ensure the relevant IT system generates reports containing only data that is suitable for publication, removing the scope for further human error.  Mr Dowden said appropriate management action will be taken but did not claryanyone would be sacked. He added: On behalf of the Cabinet Office I apologise unreservedly for any distress or inconvenience caused. Mr Dowden admitted the incident led to a briefing of police Chief Constables, necessary actions to protect high risk cases, and assessments from local police forces to check the safety of all recipients.  However, police and other agencies have now reported that there is no information to suggest any of those named on the list faced any new risk to their safety. He added: The Department has worked with the relevant organisations to ascertain the extent of the access to the data. We have no evidence that data has been exploited by a third party, or shared more widely though we continue to be vigilant.

story: NewsBoy, , who loves baked beans can only eat five a day as any more could kill himLittle Oliver Simpson loves baked beans but cant eat many of them or fish, meat, nuts or sweets, as they all could kill him because of his rare inherited conditionShareCommentsBySabina RouseKelly-Ann Mills:,  JAN NewsLittle Oliver can only have five baked beans a day " to FREE daily email alerts from mirror - daily newsSubscribe We will use your email address only for sending you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA toddler who loves baked beans can eat only five a day due to a rare disorder - as any more could leave him brain damaged or even dead. Oliver Simpson, , has inherited disorder Phenylketonuria, which means he can have only g of protein per day. It means as well as his favourite side dish, other protein-rich food including meat, fish and nuts are off the menu, as are milk, eggs and yoghurt. And he canapost even eat sweets. On Christmas Day he couldn’t eat turkey, pigs in blankets or stuffing while the rest of his family tucked into their traditional festive roast. The rare condition also known as PKU - which affects just , people worldwide - means he is unable to break down phenylalanine - an amino acid found in protein rich food. As a result it builds up in the blood, a development that can lead to seizures, tumours, brain damage, delayed mental development and ultimately death. Mum Jade, , said: “I have to be really strict with Oliver and his diet.  “He doesn’t understand, as he’s so young, but eating the wrong food could lead to brain damage, or worse.” Jade is also mum to Angel Rose, six, who doesn’t have the condition. Oliver was diagnosed with PKU following a heel prick test when he was five days old. “You’re always curious about what everyone  is eating and want to try it,” she said. “But the reality is that it could make you really ill.”  Jade, of Kentish Town, north London, won’t let Oliver go to other children’s houses for playdates. She is worried that he could accidentally eat something that could cause his protein blood levels to dangerously spike.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailItaposs been bugging me for ages, but Iaposve finally realised who Meghan Markle reminds me of.Itaposs Diane Keaton in The Godfather - the pretty ingenue who watches the man she loves be consumed by the all-powerful family business he always hated.The Royals have an awful lot in common with the Corleones. Both families enjoy immense wealth, but are forced to live in private compounds to avoid scrutiny.Their families and friends become their bodyguards, keeping their secrets and taking to the mattresses with them in times of trouble.The head of the family demands you swear an oath of loyalty, and everyone is kept in line by the consigliere or top courtier. Every son establishes their own court of supporters, who engage in power struggles with their siblings and parents.And legal issues can be an unwelcome intrusion, even on the day of a daughteraposs wedding. And there are rules that must be followed. You can do pretty much anything, run a casino badly, go bankrupt, get your toes sucked, have affairs. The worst crime is to go against the family, and the greatest punishment is exile. Perhaps Harry promised Meghan that within  years theyaposd have reformed the Royals to the extent they could be legitimate philanthropists. But in this family there are rigid lines of inheritance, and the next leader is always chosen in strict uterine order . As sixth in line to the throne, Harry is on course to become ever less-powerful in the family business. They wonapost be able to reform anything. But he, Meghan and Archie will, nevertheless, still have to follow all the rules.  When Harry married Meghan she, like Keatonaposs character Kay Adams, probably thought things would be dferent. That together they could reform an old-fashioned institution, and do something good with all that wealth and power.And theyaposve done their best. The Invictus games, the Grenfell tower cookbook, Harryaposs landmine campaign, Meghanaposs Smart Works clothing line helping poorer women into work, and her inspiration to others as a woman of colour.Heck, I was delighted just by her decision to walk down the aisle alone. Marriages are not about property being exchanged between men, but adults making a choice to walk alongside each other. If more people realised that, thereaposd be much less heartache in the world. No doubt Meghan and Harry wanted to continue his motheraposs work as a high-profile charitable campaigner. But they forgot one thing - she only ever came into her own when she left.  Once youaposre in The Firm, your friends have a path to wealth and fame by association, as well as hate and abuse. You have immense pressure, media attention, and political responsibilities.It becomes a matter of crucial national importance as to whether you are wearing a hat, and what this means for the monarchy. People discuss, at , what jewellery one of the outlaws wears to an event you both attend. Every word you speak, glance you throw, or pair of socks you put on has more ramications than an opening gambit in D chess.Youaposre not a person, when youaposre Royal. Youaposre a role. And Harry doesnapost have much of one any more.  So the best this well-intentioned, angst-ridden, slightly-uptight couple can do is to become like George and Amal Clooney - immensely wealthy and intensely secluded, with occasional forays into the public eye to do good or promote a cause, while raising their family in private. Theyaposd still be in a gilded cage, but itaposs one where - George and Amal may assure them - fewer rocks will be thrown at them.And perhaps Harry imagines that this way, they can remain friends with the family. There is no betrayal, no squealing to the feds, no abdication and subsequent exile. You can still go home for birthdays.But it takes only one ill-advised deal with a casino boss, plastic surgeon or drug gang kingpin and trouble would kick off again. Because, like the Corleones, you can never really leave this family.For all of us, it is ma fia - the nationaposs family. We watch their squabbles and compare them with our own. For centuries their character has had an impact on our history, and as long as Royals exist that obsession will not be easily dropped.Harry and Meghan could renounce everthing, and retire to a hut in Snowdonia, and thereaposd still be people with cameraphones. As millionaire philanthropists, they still wonapost be the Clooneys - every utterance will be interpreted through the lens of protocol and family politics. For Harry and Meghan itaposs not a choice of which country to live in, or what rich friends to hang out with. They have to pick their poison.The th in line to the throne can become low-profile, stay wealthy, and become ever-less scrutinised the further they move down the line of succession with every subsequent birth. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor details of your data protection rightsThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA Christian woman who waited until her wedding night to lose her virginity was horried to find she still was unable to have sex. Stephanie Muller, , wants to raise awareness of a medical condition that left her unable to consummate her marriage for two years. Stephanie and -year-old new husband Andrew decided they would wait to have sex until they wed after meeting at their local church in New York in . The couple became an item in  and courted for two years before tying the knot in May . However, on their honeymoon, attempts to have sex where thwarted when they found penetration too dficult. Stephanie ended up with a severe yeast infection which medication failed to clear up over a three-month period. During that time she found having a pelvic exam so painful that she ended up in tears and shaken. Once the infection cleared up they tried again to no avail and she said the couple ended up feeling like roommates. They eventually discovered what was at the root of the problem in January  when Stephanie was diagnosed with vaginismus by her gynaecologist. The condition results in Stephanieaposs vagina tightening up when the couple attempt to have intercourse. Stephanie said: Saving sex for my wedding night was my personal choice. I wanted to save sex for my wedding night because I didn’t want to have sex with anyone that wasn’t my husband.  I personally believe that sex is a very intimate and special thing, and I didn’t want to share that with someone  that I would not end up marrying. Stephanie said she felt ashamed that she wasn’t able to have sex with her husband and it made her feel like they were friends. My husband and I have talked about how vaginismus really de-sexualised our relationship it was almost like living with a roommate, she said. We would even be careful about other physical things because neither of us wanted to suggest trying to have sex, be disappointed, and the night ending in tears.Stephanie was referred to the Vaginismus and Women’s Therapy Centre but this would not be covered by her health insurance. So instead she was prescribed her with Vicodin, a medicine used to relieve moderate to severe pain, to have sex with her husband. In September  Stephanie looked at other things she could do and the couple decided not to let her condition affect their intimacy.  In January last year the couple undertook a five-month treatment course at Womenaposs Therapy Centre in Plainview, New York, that the break through happened and Stephanie is now healed. She said: Having vaginismus is a heavyweight, and what largely makes it so dficult is the isolation and shame that comes with it. My husband has been incredibly supportive throughout my journey with vaginismus.

title: dee must bounce back and secure second spot says keeper hamilton
story: Dundee goalkeeper Jack Hamilton insists it is vitally important they quickly bounce back from defeat to Inverness and secure second spot in the Championship.The Dark Blues fell to fourth in the table after a - defeat to second-placed ICT at Dens on Saturday and now lag six points behind the Highlanders.Sitting in the final promotion play-off spot is far from where the Dee would have hoped to have been at this stage of the season.However, Hamilton admits they can only look at themselves to recty that and make their path to any potential push for Premiership promotion clear as early as possible.“You don’t want to be coming towards the end of the season wondering where you’ll finish. Ideally, we’ve got to be finishing second,” he said.“It takes out that extra two games in the play-offs and that’s where we want to be, that’s what we’re looking towards and realistically we’ve got the squad to do that.“We’ve got to look to win every game and it’s down to us really. Dundee United are sitting  points ahead so,they weren’t to win the league it’d be a disaster on their part.“We’ll just concentrate on ourselves. There’s no point looking at anybody , each week we don’t look at other results thinking ‘whatwe do this and that’ we just focus on our own performances and how we’re going to beat teams.“We need to start getting three points on the board again.”Ending their four-match unbeaten run, particularly after a morale-boosting derby draw the weekend previous, with a loss against the Caley Jags stung for Dundee and Hamilton.And the -year-old is determined to put that right as soon as possible with three points when third-placed Ayr United come to town on Saturday.The former Hearts man added: “It was really disappointing off the back of a good run of games and it just wasn’t acceptable.“We started sloppy and it just continued throughout. It wasn’t a nice one on Saturday.“In the derby, in the second half in particular, I thought the boys were magnicent and then you’re looking for the same as that against Inverness on Saturday but we started off poorly and that just continued throughout the game. vw, px"  “We knew what they were all about, they’re sitting second in the league and they’re a good side.“They were a team we had to beat but we’ll sit down and watch the game and we’ll see where we went wrong.“We’ve got to recty that in the next game looking forward.“We just need to get back to the second half of the derby, that’s the performance we’re capable of and we’ve got a right good team in that dressing-room – it’s just about getting that consistency and kicking on from there.“Everybody out there on the pitch knows how good we are inidually so it’s one of those ones where we are frustrated.Dundee - Inverness: Dismal Dee drop to fourth with ICT defeat" src"https:www.eveningtelegraph fp dundee---inverness-dismal-dee-drop-to-fourth-with-ict-defeat embed # secretXqUmxEai" data-secret"XqUmxEai" width"" "" frameborder"" marginwidth"" margin"" scrolling"no"“We need to assess the game and look to see where we can improve.“Going forward, we need to get the three points against Ayr.”And Hamilton knows they need to get the fans back on side after many voiced their displeasure on Saturday.“It’s not nice and you can feel and understand the supporters’ frustration.“They’re entitled to their opinion, quite rightly so because they support the team.“They want the highest possible achievement for Dundee and likewise so do we, so when things aren’t working out as we’d like they’re going to be frustrated.“We’ve got to do it for them as well as ourselves.”

title: dundee 0 2 inverness dismal dee drop to fourth with ict defeat
story: Dundee dropped to fourth in the Championship table as they fell to a - defeat to Inverness at Dens Park.First-half goals from Aaron Doran and James Keatings did the damage as John Robertson#s Caley Jags strengthened their grip on second spot.Ayr winning at Dunfermline meant the Dark Blues dropped to the fourth and final promotion play-off spot,  points behind leaders Dundee United.Dee boss James McPake stuck with the same line-up which earned a point in the Dundee derby with -year-old Fin Robertson starting in the middle of the park after a terric display at Tannadice.Inverness were the first to threaten but Nikolay Todorov could only head Miles Storey#s cross over the bar after three minutes.Caley skipper Carl Tremarco went closer on nine minutes as he got on the end of another Storey cross after a period of pressure. However, Dark Blues keeper Jack Hamilton gathered the header comfortably.Hamilton then made a smart stop from a whipped Keatings free-kick minutes later as the visitors continued to push for the opener.On  minutes Charlie Trafford forced a routine save out of Hamilton before, just a minute later, Inverness got the goal their play deserved.In acres of space down the right, full-back Shaun Rooney had the freedom of Dens Park to pick out Doran in the centre of the box and the Irish attacker duly lashed home from  yards.On  minutes, ICT were two to the good. From their own corner, Dundee compounded to lose possession and allowed the Highlanders to break.Former Dundee United man Keatings led the charge and finished the counter attack off himself, coolly slotting beyond a helpless Hamilton in the home goal.The Dark Blues huffed and puffed for the remainder of a dismal first half for them but were unable to lay a glove on Inverness as the boos rang out among the sizeable home support on the half-time whistle.Four minutes into the second period, Dundee forced Mark Ridgers into his first save of the afternoon as the ICT goalie stooped to turn Jordan Marshall#s long-range effort behind for a corner.Jordan McGhee was next to test Ridgers, firing in a dipping effort just before the hour mark, but the Caley stopper was able to gather.Moments later, Paul McGowan#s header from a deep Sean Mackie cross forced Ridgers to tip over as the Dee sought a way back into the contest.On  minutes, Kane Hemmings laid in Marshall but the left-back saw his effort from  yards deflected behind.Inverness# front four continued to look threatening but, largely, the Dee defence kept them quiet in the second .However, McPake#s men were unable to carve a way through an organised ICT defence with the rookie boss cutting a frustrated and under-pressure figure throughout.With Ayr and Dunfermline to face next, Dundee will certainly need to perform a lot betterthey are to stay in the mix for the promotion play-offs come the end of the season.Dundee XI : HamiltonKerr, Meekings , McGhee, Marshall Robertson, Dorrans, McGowan, MackieJohnson , Hemmings.Subs not used: Ferrie , Forster, Byrne, Moore and Cameron.Inverness XI : RidgersRooney, Donaldson, McHattie, TremarcoTrafford , Vincent StoreyKeatings Doran Todorov .Subs not used: Mackay , McCart, Curry and MacGregor.Referee: Don Robertson.Att: ,.

title: mcpake laments poor dee display
story: Dundee manager James McPake believes their - defeat to Inverness at Dens on Saturday was as poor as they’ve been all season.The Dark Blues went down with a whimper to the Caley Jags as first-half goals from Aaron Doran and James Keatings had the game over as a contest after  minutes.And boss James ranks the loss up there with the - derby defeat to rivals Dundee United and the - capitulation against Partick at Dens.Askedhis side struggle to find he right levels at home, the Dee gaffer said: “No, I don’t think so.“You can pick games at home and away from home where we’ve been really good so it’s about being the way we are when we’re good and getting after teams.Dundee - Inverness CTGoals from Aaron Doran and @jameskeatings give nd placed Inverness CT victory at Dens Park against Dundee.@ICTFC @DundeeFC @spfl pic oCfXziEkmdash Sky Sports ScotlandJanuary , “On Saturday, for that first  minutes, it was as poor as we’ve been all season so I can’t even look at the other games where we have been poor.“We started the game really badly on Saturday and I don’t think it’s got anything to do with where we’re playing.“We just never came out the blocks the way we should’ve on the back of a half-decent run.”And that lack of momentum carried over from the - derby draw at Tannadice the weekend previous, given they were also on a four-match unbeaten run, surprised James.He added: “There should have been .“We were on the back of a half-decent run of form and I mean that with the consistency of our performances.“It looked like we knew what we were going to get over the past month or so in terms of the performance.“The energy and the drive in the team wasn’t there on Saturday.“Inverness were the opposite. They had a real poor result the previous weekendand you’d think we should be really confident and start this game really well in front of our own fans.“It was really disappointing the way we started the game and I don’t think we gave ourselves any chance.“We didn’t get into the game at all in the first  minutes, they get the goals and the damage was done. It was really poor.”

title: youth prospect declan glass has sights set on permanent role in dundee united first team
story: Dundee United’s latest youth import hopes while form is temporary, Glass is permanent at Tannadice.Nineteen-year-old Declan Glass made histo the Tangerines first team at Queen of the South on Saturday after being recalled from loan at Cove Rangers.And he has his sights firmly set on a prolonged spell in the first team after his first appearance since September .He told the Tele: “I’ve been on two loans, to Airdrie last season and right away to Cove this time, so it has been a while – it doesn’t feel like that long, to be honest.“I’m delighted to be back. Dundee United is where I want to be, where I want to be playing so it was really good to be back on Saturday.“To get recalled early gave me a boost going into the weekend’s game and to go straight into the team was a bonus.“Then to get three points, I’m delighted.“I found out the start of last week I was coming back.“The gaffer spoke to me and I went up to Cove just to say bye to the boys.“Paul Hartley spoke to me and told me to keep doing what I had done up there at United.“The gaffer here has emphasised that as well – hopefully, I took my chance on Saturday.”Glass shone in League Two as Cove lead the way at the top of the table, scoring seven goals in  appearances and winning the ision’s Player of the Month award in August.The teenager s to the club with United sitting pretty,  points clear of the rest of the Championship and on the back of an -match unbeaten run that’s brought  victories.And he feels the spell at the top of League Two with the Aberdeen club will serve him well as he s to Tannadice.He added: “I was still in at United every day during my loan and working under the gaffer so I’ve come into the team in a good position, knowing what the gaffer expects.“It’s going to be a huge second half to the season.“It’s going to be all about consolidating our league position and pushing for the title.“It’s about getting as many points on the board as possible and trying to wrap things up as quickly as possible.“It was like for like at Cove, we were battling away at the top of the table there, too.“I think it probably helped me going out to a club like that where we were pushing for promotion as well.“To come back to United in this position is nice, to be fair!“I don’t think our lead means anything, though – we need to keep winning games and focus on each Saturday as it comes.”The next Saturday coming is another tough away trip to Partick Thistle.Ian McCall’s side are on an upward trajectory with three wins and a draw in their last five matches as they battle to get away from the foot of the table.Glass is targeting another start for the Tangerines at Firhill but knows they’ll have to be on their game to make it  wins from their last . vw, px"  “Partick are a big club and probably don’t think they should be where they are,” Glass added.“We are battling to win a league, they are battling for survival, which is maybe a surprise, so both teams have a lot to play for.“I expect another really tough game, another battle but, hopefully, we can come out on top.“Last weekend Queens were tough, they are always dficult away, they pride themselves on being a good home side.“Not many teams get three points there and I think we showed a dferent side of us, we can go to places like Palmerston and scrape wins.“I thinkyou want to win a title, that’s huge.”

title: end of an era as aecc arena be flattened
story: Work to knock down Aberdeen#s former exhibition centre is expected to begin in the coming weeks.Aberdeen City Council submitted a building warrant to demolish existing buildings at the Aberdeen Exhibition and Conference Centrein Bridge of Don, alongside agents Fairhurst.The site is no longer in use following the opening of the PJ Live arena in August last year.The multi-million-pound state-of-the-art event complex, which is in Bucksburn, now hosts all major events. vw, px"  The AECC first opened its doors in  and comprised of conference facilities and a multi-purpose arena.It has now been permanently closed.A building warrant was submitted in September to demolish buildings at the site including the main arena, which has now been approved by the local authority.Aberdeen City Council co-leader Douglas Lumsden said now the building warrant has been granted, the “intention” would be for that work to start “immediately”.He added: “That might include internal works first which people won’t be able to see.”As well as the removal of the old main arena building, the covered walkway that connects to the section of the conference centre next to the Holiday Inn Express will also be removed.It is expected that the value of the work to be undertaken will be around £,.The warrant has an expiry date of January   and all work must be completed by then.It is understood that the remaining conference centre will be retained as well as the nearby park-and-ride facility.Talks regarding the future use of the site are still ongoing.Plans were previously submitted to the local authority by developers Henry Boot in May  for the land, which hoped to create a mixed use development including approximately  residential units, properties for commercial and business use, a recycling centre and park-and-ride facility.The application is still pending and there was a number of documents uploaded on to the site in , along with a letter of objection received last year.It stated: “The site would have been better used as a new north-east HQ and training hub for Police Scotland with Queen Street being disposed of.“There would be ample space to create a specialist training facility, which Police Scotland does not have anywhere north of the central belt.”Discussions have also been under way with the King’s Community Church over the site, with the church keen to move from its base on King Street.The church began in  with a small gathering before it moved to the city centre church in  where it has remained.An Aberdeen City Council spokeswoman said: “A building warrant to demolish the arena at the old AECC and a covered walkway to the adjacent hotel has been approved by the planning authority.”

title: 12 months on from new aberdeen deal its sam cosgrove who deserves all the credit for rise
story: Exactly a year ago today Sam Cosgrove signed a contract extension tying him to Pittodrie until summer .Viewed  months on, tying up the striker’s long-term future was a masterstroke from the Aberdeen board.It would now take a multi-million-pound bid to force the Dons’ hand to sell a player who cost just £, in January .That could be tested this month as Middlesbrough, Derby County and Stoke are all tracking the -year-old.Prolic scoring does not go unnoticed and Aberdeen are braced for any approach or bid from England for Cosgrove this month.McInnes hailed the role head of recruitment Russ Richardson played in highlighting the then-unknown Carlisle United reserve player.He also acknowledged the Dons and the club’s coaching staff for giving Cosgrove the  to thrive.But ultimately it is the player, who netted  goals in , who is responsible for becoming one of the hottest strikers in Scotland.McInnes said: “Sam came to a club that could make him stronger, better and more confident.“All my staff have played a part in that.“My head of recruitment, Russ Richardson, also deserves so much praise for identying Sam.“When Russ watched Sam he liked how he received the ball and liked how he moved.“But ultimately Sam’s rise is not down to Russ, the staff or myself.“It is Sam who deserves the most for actually making the most of his opportunity. He relished the opportunity at Aberdeen and played the biggest part himself.”Officially Cosgrove netted  goals in  but the striker also netted a further two just days after penning his new deal.He scored both goals in Aberdeen’s - friendly win over United Arab Emirates’ side Dibba Al-Hisn in a friendly in Dubai last January.Cosgrove suffered a shaky start to his time at Aberdeen when sent off in his debut against Celtic on February  .He would have to wait  months since signing for his first goal when netting a double in a - defeat of St Mirren in October.That December he hit the goal trail, netting in five straight games to bag seven goals.McInnes insists they were looking for an alternative to prolic striker Adam Rooney. That December proved they had found one.Aberdeen then moved quickly to tie him up on a long-term deal beyond the contract that ran until summer .McInnes said: “We were looking for an alternative striker to Adam Rooney who we could work with and try to make better.“Jayden Stockley had obviously been with us but we knew we could maybe sell him back into England.“Jayden was maybe getting a bit frustrated that he wasn’t always playing ahead of Adam.“We wanted somebody a bit dferent with a bit of size.“When we first signed him that was something we spoke about but also to not be too dependent on his size in and around the box, to be a sharper striker and concentrate more on movement, positioning and anticipation rather than just letting the ball hit your head.“So thatteams sit in at home and want to defend their box, we have a striker there we can put in the box.“Sam has learned to use his size a lot better since being here.“He has relished the opportunity.”Cosgrove’s prolic scoring streak quickly caught the imagination of the Aberdeen supporters.They began chanting “Sam Cosgrove Ballon d’Or” at games in recognition of the successor to Rooney, who hit -plus goals for three successive season.Cosgrove has already smashed in  goals this season and became the first Aberdeen player to reach that milestone since Duncan Shearer in .He was denied the opportunity to add to that tally by a two-game ban for the final two games before the winter shutdown for a challenge on Celtic defender Kristoffer Ajer.Aberdeen appealed the straight red, arguing Cosgrove clearly won the ball, but the red and the ban were upheld.McInnes said: “There is no doubt that once Sam became really accepted by the supporters that meant so much to him.“For any young player,they know the supporters, the staff the players and the manager are behind him it means so much.“But particularly to know the supporters are right behind you because you can respond to that.“Sam has certainly responded.”

title: meet rg mowat owner of the fulmar
story: Colin CameronUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAt the end of November we asked readers for help to unravel the mystery of a yacht log book which was posted to the paper with no clues as to its origin.And, not for the first time, Argyllshire Advertiser readers have come up trumps and we now know a little more about the boat#s owner, named only as RG Mowat in the log book.The  log book gives an account of the voyages of the -foot gaff cutter #Fulmar# and the adventures of her colourful crew. Its dog-eared pages contain neatly-typed records, precise drawings and fascinating photographs.The log#s mystery is deepened by the fact no names are given other than the nicknames #Tanky#, #Bosun#, #Skipper# and #Pilot#. The only crew member named is pet dachshund #Major#.The log does record the Fulmar#s home port was Tighnabruaich and the owner was RG Mowat, but few details on Mr Mowat could be found.Lord Weir of Lochhead, Achahoish, contacted the newspaper to pass on information on Commander Ralph G Mowat.During the Second World War, Commander Mowat was a Royal Navy Captain, latterly in command of a cruiser. At the end of the war, he and his ship entered Copenhagen, where he took the surrender of the German troops.Clive Brown from Ardfern added some post-war detail. He revealed: #Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , was a distinguished member of Clyde Cruising Clubbest known as being, for  years, the honorary editor of the CCC Sailing Directions . These were # and indeed remain # a #must have# for everyone who navigates their way among the many lochs and islands of Scotland#s west coast. They were colloquially known as the #Blue Book# and published at that time as a hardback. He also served as CCC Rear Commodore -.#Mr Brown also provided an extract from the book #Clyde Cruising Club, The First One Hundred Years -# which states Ralph Mowat received an RYA Award for services to yachting in  but refused to accept honorary membership of the club. In recompense, his widow Mary was elected an honorary member in , after his death.Tighnabruaich man Alan Wilson contacted Clyde sailing legend Ian Nicolson, who was fairly sure he recalled racing against the #Fulmar# in the s.Mr Nicolson said:#Old Man Mowat, as I remember him, was a typical ex Royal Navy officer. He treated me as a young upstart, which I was, but we got on well because I wrote a bit for Clyde Cruising Club publications. He lived in Clarkston on the edge of Glasgow.#Clyde Cruising Club itself cannot help with information on the Fulmar. Club secretary Jenner Rollands contacted the Advertiser and confirmed CCC sadly lost all its records when the Carrick, moored on the River Clyde, sank in . At the time, the club#s office was aboard her.Closer to home, Ardrishaig man Billy Paterson called into the Advertiser offices to say his father, Ardrishaig Primary School headmaster Gilbert Paterson, had crewed the yacht Fulmar.Mr Paterson still has mementoes from his father#s trips in the form of gts from Commander Mowat, including a paperweight from , a copper and brass barrel ashtray dated  and a brass model yacht with #Fulmar # engraved on it.Thanks to everyone who contacted the Advertiser with their memories.We now know a little more about Commander Ralph G Mowat, RN , owner of the Fulmar.Details about the crew of #Tanky#, #Bosun# and #Pilot# remain, however, sketchy, soanyone out there knows any more#

title: news from the districts january 3 2020
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsThe Scottish Salmon Companyhas provided Cowal Badminton Association with funding towards new sporting equipment following its latest round of Community Fund awards.Cowal Badminton Association received a £ donation to cover the costs of rackets and shuttlecocks for their new practice nights.The association was founded almost  years ago, playing a vital role in bringing the community of Dunoon together by offering weekly social events that are inclusive to all.Development co-ordinator at Cowal Badminton Association, Craig Anderson, said: #The funding from SSC has enabled us to purchase new rackets and tubes of shuttlecocks, which our members will be able to use. We hope this will remove a barrier to new members joining, as they will no longer have to provide their own equipment. On behalf of the team, we thank the Scottish Salmon Company for its kind donation.#Volunteers are being offered a chance to work off some of the seasonal over eating, as a work party is held at Tarbert Castle.Meeting at am tomorrow , the group will set about planting trees and removing brambles until around lunchtime.The perfect opportunity to catch up following the festivities, all willing to help will be made welcome and tea and coffee will be on offer to the hard working volunteers.A #Scandinavian# approach to self-sufficiency is being proposed by Craignish Community Council.With Argyll and Bute Council being unable extend their gritting areas, community council members picked up bags of grit from the council depot. Four bags have been placed by the Glebe houses, five up Ardlarach Road on the pavement nearer the top and three for the steeper bits on the road up to Lunga.Empty bags can be handed into Ardfern Shop and they will be re-filled.In a Facebook post Craignish Community Council said: #It seems that in future we may be best taking the more Scandinavian approach of managing it ourselves for those areas beyond council gritting.#The weather was chilly but dry for the Boxing Day shinty match in Strachur, attracting a good number of spectators .In the annual under-s versus over-s clash, the old boys just about squeaked it - after an exciting match at Strachurmore Sports Centre.Veteran Ally Mirrlees opened the scoring with a well-taken goal just five minutes into the match. Ten minutes later Lewis Montgomery levelled matters, before another from Montgomery beat over-s keeper Ross MacDonald to give the youngsters a half-time lead slimmer than most of the waists in the opposition ranks.The game was to turn in the second half, as Neil Nicolson scored twice for the old boys and the victory was theirs, despite goalie Willie McGladdery pulling off some good saves for the under-s.The Niall Campbell Memorial Trophy was presented to winning captain Ross MacDonald by Mr Campbell#s son John, and a very sociable evening followed in the Strachurmore pavilion.PIC:All smiles after an entertaining match to blow away the festive cobwebs. no_aStrachurBoxingDay

title: a bumper year for rallying
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwards was a big year for Argyll locals with the much anticipatedof one of the biggest events in Scotland on the doorstep, Mull Rally, and the continued running of the Mach  Stages and Argyll Stages in Dunoon. Three events all within a stones throw of Mid Argyll.Jamie Miller was the only local to enter this event, starting his Scottish Tarmac Rally Championshipcampaign for the year in the rapid  Citroen CR. Paul Hunter, swapping his pacenotes for spanners, was on hand to assist Jamie throughout the season. Conditions were said to have been tricky as Knockhill has its own micro-climate, which consists purely of rain, wind, snow, ice, wind and wind. Sadly it wasn#t to be at Knockhill for the team with mechanical failure ending their day after stage two.The first closed road event to take place in England, after the approval of closed road rallying for the UK, was the first event for the famousGTi. Unfortunately for Kirsty Mochrie her licence can only be upgraded to stage events from single venue use when she turns , so it was theof the pairing of Innes Mochrie and Paul Hunter to represent Mid Argyll south of the border. The pair, finding the conditions tricky in the narrow lanes after the top seed cars had been pulling mud from verges and ditches, managed to bounce the wee metro over the first loop of four stages until the gearbox had enough on the fth test.Following the cancelling of Inverness# Snowman Rally earlier in the year, this was now first round of the Scottish Rally Championshipfor Dougie Watt and Ian Parker, and it was interesting to say the least. A glance outside in the morning to see about four inches of snow lying on the roof of the MK Escort was a surprise for a start. A very wet and muddy day saw the pair make it to the finish in one piece which is more than can be said for the clutch cable that snapped about one mile into the final stage, however clinching their first class win of the season was the best start to the championship.With Kirsty #Wee Mo# Mochrie in the co-drivers seat in the rapid Corsa of Steven Hay , a fair pace was set by the pair throughout the day sitting as high as th until they unfortunately had to take a split early to save damaging the car. Back out the next stage and still setting a blistering top  pace in the Corsa, including some hang time on both the jumps.Jamie, back out in the fit C, had bad luck once again. This time an overshoot on a square right and a struggle to get the car started again after a stall sadly earned him a stage max on stage two. Still setting top  times on the day he ended nd which was a fair effort when you include a stage maximum time.Ian was out this time with Fraser #Flat oot Fraz# Smithafter winning an entry to the rally at the STRC Awards in January. Flying out the gates and onto their second lap on the first stage then pop, driveshaft burst. Towed in and sorted, both covered in CV Grease, they made it back out for a skid around and on a mission to tear up some old tarmac tyres.The Granite Stages, now held at RAF Leuchars would see Eoghan Anderson make ato the passenger seat for a hurl in the immaculate MK Escort of Martin Murray. Smiling ear to ear all day, with Bill eagerly awaiting histo the service area for the stage report, they finished th overall.Ian was out with Greg Inglisin his fluorescent Orange Lotus Exige and it was eyes on the prize for STRC points for Greg. A clean day saw Greg really getting to grips with the car on some surprisingly fast stages including a tickle of the limiter in fth saw the pair finish third overall.Back together and with the small repairs from the Speyside done it was time for the Furnace MK toto the woods. A steady run over the opening two stages, Dougie and Ian found their feet after the #off# at the Speyside sent them into service lying th. From seeing their overall position they knew they had to get back into it on the next stage, however on the road section to start stage three there was issues selecting gear and the pair decided to call it a day # damage limitation was the right call, as the input shaft was on its last legs.Jamie was back on the pace for this one, setting a th fastest stage time on the opening test. Sitting th overall heading into stage five was impressive given the competition on the day. Bad luck unfortunately, however, was to .Eoghan was again out with Martin in the MK for a blast. Sadly it was an early bath, retired after stage two but again, as always, enjoying every minute while it lasted.The Argyll rally had been known to have rough and challenging stages the previous two years. Not this time. Ian and Dougie couldn#t believe how good the stages were in comparison to previous years, an absolute joy of an event with the Escort not missing a beat all day on its #shakedown# for the big one. Valuable class points added to the scorecard too, with them ending the event nd overall. The rally had struggled with entries this year and will now run in  as a closed road rally, run by Mull Car Club.Team Mochrie were back together for this one in the Mightyagain and Innes was cutting some questionable shapes in the garage, performing his annual Mach rain dance. Taking chunks of time from his first passes of the stages would see them ring the #s neck and clinch th.Jamie#s luck had finally turned, the C singing all weekend and netting him a topper of th overall and th fastest over the final stage too.Duncan Maclean was back in the driving seat with Ian alongside, giving himself and the car a shakedown before Mull. The freshly rebuilt #blue bullet# was looking superb and managed to finish looking just as sweet. A couple of small teething problems were sorted on the day and the new main focus was to have power steering fitted before Mull # poor Dochy lost about a stone over two days with the effort needed to swing the wee pug around the #s and chicanes.In August Dougie and Ian competed on the Vetomies Rally. A national grade event run alongside the WRC Rally Finland event. Three other crews from Scotland also headed over to sample #the fastest rally in the world#. The stages were unbelievable. Fast, cresty, wide, flowing with a brilliantly smooth surface. The whole event was just surreal. The duo finished the event th overall and more importantly the fastest Scottish crew.Once the car had ed from Finland it was quickly jacked up, checked and loaded onto the trailer the same day for the journey north. Due to two DNFson the Speyside and Scottish, Dougie and Ian had to make the trip to be in with any chance of regaining their class lead in the SRC. Ending the day first in the class meant they were heading into the final round with the lead.Jamie was back out for another counting round of the STRC. Enjoying his day and pushing the wee C on in the blistering heat netted Jamie and co-driver Ian Mccullochrd overall. He must have been relaxed in the heat as in between stages he was off with the overalls and on with the baby lotion, topping up the tan.Ian was back out with Greg in the Lotus. Another fantastic drive from Greg, finishing ninth with the championship title race firmly the primary goal.The final round for the MK and an important one # a DNF here could see Dougie and Ian losing the class lead in the championship. A battle with their rival who they had been chasing all season, Paddy Munro, would come down to the last stage, as the pair were six seconds down on Paddy heading into the final test. Probably one of the duo#s best stages all year, the final push to claim the class honours came down to the finish of the last stage on the last rally of the year. One second! They had taken the class win and the championship.The first event this year for Craig Callander and son Ross would see them prepare Craig#s gravel spec Subaru Impreza at the last minute to take on their favourite event. The #Japanese Tractor# was a fair handful, a light steering alignment issue and a boost problem gave the pair some trouble although finishing th overall made up for the hassle. A fair result given Craig#s absence from tarmac for four years.Returning from the shed with his freshly painted Sunbeam was Alister Macarthur, this time with Claire Tilleyalongside. The freshly fettled #beam was looking and sounding good # crossing the finish th overall after two years out of the seat.Dochy and Ian were back out in the #blue bullet.# All was going well until they had a spin coming over a crest into a square left, losing the bumper and damaging the gear linkage. They managed to get the car back to the end of the Saturday afternoon leg to repair the gear linkage and almost stole the yellow bumper from the recce car until some legends appeared with the duo#s bumper in the back of their Land Rover. Back out onto the  mile #long one# on Saturday night and they had an issue # after a heavy landing over a crest the rear shocker bolt broke, making the car a handful to keep in a straight line. They had to finish another two stages before they could make it back to service, so a finish was all they wanted at this point # th overall and Dochys fourth finish in a row on Mull.Without doubt the driver to watch was Innes and his newly acquired co-driver Lewis Grfiths . The Mightywas spotted airborne at any chance, with the hydro can suspension screaming for a break at each service halt. It was almost all over as the nearside cv joint sheared and the car took a wild turn to the left # both Innes and Lewis thought they would end up IN the Belachroy pub. They managed to make it over the Lochs to the end of the final stage, claiming st overall.Eoghan was back out with Martin to settle the score from the DNF at the summer stages. Sadly a stage maximum time on stage two scuppered their chances of the overall result they were hoping for, however they did set some impressive times, clocking a th fastest time on the final stage.Jamie, back out for the final round of the STRC, was looking to continue his good run from the Pendragon and set a seventh fastest time on stage three in the extremely wet and tricky conditions. Trying to get his money#s worth from his entry fee Jamie, however, decided to take an extra couple of miles on the penultimate stage. Still, the C ran well all day and the conditions suited the car perfectly.Ian was back out with Greg and this time he was aiming to become the Scottish Tarmac Rally Champion for . They set off with five cars in the same class and they had to win the class to get Greg the honours. Setting the pace early they were leading throughout the event. Finishing the event first in their class and third overall meant the job was done # Greg claimed the championship win.The last event of the year saw Kirsty back in the co-drivers seat, gaining even more experience on her path to upgrading her licence. Some typical Knockhill weather was in store as Kirsty had her first taste of RWD rallying in the Mazda MX of Paul Sheard. Kirsty guided Paul around the very wet stages to claim th overall and some valuable points on the board for Paul#s Motorsport News Championship campaign.Special thanks to Alasdair MacConnell who has travelled many miles to don an orange bib and stand in the rain, wind and heat, all to show his support and play a vital part in any event. And to Gavin #Top Tog# Brown, who has been an avid rally man for years and continued to watch us all through the lens, capturing some of our most heroic moments. was a busy year, with a few of us still tinkering away in sheds.  will hopefully see theof Ally and Del Galbraith in their #new# MK Escort and Donald Bowness in the giant killing Nova making aafter some time out.PICS:Dougie Watt and Ian Parker flying in Finland before winning in Aberdeen Photo: Jii Pihlaja. no_a_RallyFinlandFather and son duo Craig and Ross Callendar came in th overall at this year#s Mull Rally. Photo: West Coast Photography. no_aMullRally_CraigCallanderEuan Thorburn took a drama filled Argyll Rally victory, adding to his  win on the event. Photos: Eddie Kelly Motorsport Photography. no_aargyllrallyInnes Mochrie, Lochgilphead and Lewis Grfiths finished Mull Rally st overall. Photo: West Coast Photography. no_aMullRally_InnesMochrie

title: bute meets ayrshire in memory of calum
story: Rachel CarruthersUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe NowAn Argyll and Bute charity has joined forces with the Prince#s Foundation to offer families living with cancer short getaways at a five-star, self-catering cottage at Dumfries House estate, East Ayrshire.Caroline Speirs co-founded Calum#s Cabin with her husband Duncan and daughter Jenna to provide holiday homes on the Isle of Bute for children suffering from cancer or a cancer-related disease. Caroline and Duncan were parents to Calum, who sadly passed away aged  after being diagnosed with a brain tumour.Knowing he and his family lived in a beautul part of the world, Calum wanted children suffering from cancer to come to Bute for special getaways where the entire family could cherish quality time together and recharge their batteries for what may lie ahead.The charity now runs several holiday homes on Bute and private flats in Glasgow for families travelling to the city for treatments at the Beatson West of Scotland Cancer Care and Royal Hospital for Children.Dumfries House Lodge is a -room, five-star country guest house with two self-catering cottages, all staffed round the clock.Eight families have been referred through the children#s charity so far to enjoy a four-night stay free of charge.Caroline said: #To allow Calum#s Cabin families to be helped in such a special way is an absolute honour.
