title: iran-launches-missiles-us-bases-iraq
story: President Donald Trump insisted ldquoAll is well! after Iran fired surface-to-surface missiles at two Iraqi bases housing US troops.He promised to make a statement to the nation on Wednesday morning about the increasingly precarious situation with Iran.Mr Trump offered no immediate indication of whether he would retaliate, and stayed out of sight as news of the missile strikes emerged.:Donald Trump threatens Iranian cultural sites despite war crime concernsBut he tweeted that an assessment of casualties and damages was under way. The initial outlook, he said, was ldquoSo far, so good!Iran struck back at the US for the killing of a top Iranian general, firing a series of ballistic missiles at two Iraqi bases housing US troops in Iraq.Iranian state TV said it was in revenge for the US killing of Revolutionary Guard General Qassem Soleimani, whose death last week in an American drone strike near Baghdad prompted calls for avenge.All is well! Missiles launched from Iran at two military bases located in Iraq. Assessment of casualties  damages taking place now. So far, so good! We have the most powerful and well equipped military anywhere in the world, by far! I will be making a statement tomorrow morning.mdash Donald J. TrumpJanuary , Gen Soleimanirsquos killing and the strikes by Iran came as tensions have been rising steadily across the Middle East after President Donald Trumprsquos decision to unilaterally withdraw America from Tehranrsquos nuclear deal with world powers.They also marked the first time in recent years that Washington and Tehran have attacked each other directly rather than through proxies in the region. It raised the chances of open conflict erupting between the two enemies, which have been at odds since Iranrsquos  Islamic Revolution.Iran initially announced only one strike, but US officials confirmed both.US defence officials were at the White House, probably to discuss options with Mr Trump, who launched the strike on Soleimani while facing an upcoming impeachment trial in the Senate.Iranrsquos Revolutionary Guard warned the US and its regional allies against retaliating over the missile attack against the Ain al-Asad air base in Iraqrsquos western Anbar province. The Guard issued the warning via a statement carried by Iranrsquos state-run IRNA news agency.:Analysis: Trump knows Iran weakness will hamper re-election oddsldquoWe are warning all American allies, who gave their bases to its terrorist army, that any territory that is the starting point of aggressive acts against Iran will be targeted, it said. It also threatened Israel.After the strikes, a former Iranian nuclear negotiator posted a picture of the Islamic Republicrsquos flag on Twitter, appearing to mimic Mr Trump who posted an American flag following the killing of Gen Soleimani and others on Friday in a drone strike in Baghdad.Ain al-Asad air base was first used by American forces after the  US-led invasion that toppled dictator Saddam Hussein, and later saw American troops stationed there amid the fight against the Islamic State group in Iraq and Syria. It houses about , US and coalition forces.Two Iraqi security officials said at least one of the missiles appeared to have struck a plane at the base, igniting a fire. It was not immediately clear whether it was an Iraqi or US jet.About  Norwegian troops also were on the air base but no injuries were reported, Brynjar Stordal, a spokesperson for the Norwegian Armed Forces told the Associated Press.Mr Trump visited the sprawling Ain al-Asad air base, about  miles west of Baghdad, in December , making his first presidential visit to troops in the region.He did not meet with any Iraqi officials at the time, and his visit inflamed sensitivities about the continued presence of US forces in Iraq. Vice President Mike Pence also has visited the base.Iranian state TV said the Guardrsquos aerospace ision that controls Iranrsquos missile program launched the attack, which it said was part of an operation called Martyr Soleimani.The US also acknowledged another missile attack on a base in Irbil in Iraqrsquos semi-autonomous Kurdish region.ldquoAs we evaluate the situation and our response, we will take all necessary measures to protect and defend US personnel, partners and allies in the region, said Jonathan Hoffman, an assistant to the US defence secretary.Wednesdayrsquos revenge attack happened just hours after crowds in Iran mourned Gen Soleimani at his funeral. It also came as the US continued to reinforce its own positions in the region and warned of an unspecied threat to shipping from Iran in the regionrsquos waterways, crucial routes for global energy supplies.US embassies and consulates from Asia to Africa and Europe issued security alerts for Americans.A stampede broke out Tuesday at Gen Soleimanirsquos funeral, and at least  people were killed and more than  injured as thousands thronged the procession, Iranian news reports said.The stampede took place in Gen Soleimanirsquos hometown of Kerman as his coffin was being borne through the city in south-eastern Iran, said Pirhossein Koulivand, head of Iranrsquos emergency medical services.ldquoUnfortunately as a result of the stampede, some of our compatriots have been injured and some have been killed during the funeral processions, Mr Koulivand said, and state TV quoted him as saying that  had died and  had been injured.Gen Soleimanirsquos burial was delayed, with no new time given, because of concerns about the huge crowd at the cemetery, the semi-official ISNA news agency said.Meanwhile, everyone on board a Ukrainian aircraft carrying around  passengers and crew that crashed close to Iranrsquos capital, Tehran, has died, Iranian state television has reported.The plane had taken off from Imam Khomeini International Airport, the report said.It went down in farmland outside of the city.Authorities initially blamed a mechanical problem for the crash.

title: bid-save-glasgow-mount-florida-bowling-club-housing-plans-submitted
story: Mount Floridarsquos Community Trust is hosting a public drop in session tonight and Saturday morning to discuss a planning application to build a block of flats at the former Bowling Club on Carmunnock Road.Members of Mount Florida Bowling Club, whose membership dropped from  to , voted to close their facility in  and decided to dispose of the land to Noah Managements and Developments Ltd. In October  the Community Trust submitted a bid to the council to develop a sports facility. They want to buy the bowling club to make this possible.Nicola Smith, director of Mount Florida Community Trust, said: ldquoWe would have tried to help the bowling club years ago had they let us know they were struggling to attract members.ldquoWe totally accept that this site could be more.ldquoWe want to offer dferent sports to the community as well. We would offer a membership for those who wanted to remain part of the bowling club.ldquoWe would also like to see a tennis court developed at the site as well as a community hub. Mount Florida Primary School would benefit from public green space as their play ground is all tarred.ldquoThis facility has been in our community for  years and should be used for  years to come.Noah Managements and Developments Ltd has said that a ldquosubstantial pocket of publicly accessible open space will be provided by their development.If successful two apartment blocks of equal scale, will be aligned to Carmunnock Road and set back from the existing planted embankments.Duplex apartments would be created on the ground floor and a series of generous one-bed and two-bed apartments would feature on upper floors and include private balconies.Residents have until Thursday, January  to submit their response to these proposals on the councilrsquos website.Ms Smith continued: ldquoWe are hosting these drop-in sessions to tell people about the development proposals and show them how they can navigate the councilrsquos website and submit their response.ldquoThis application was submitted just before Christmas so we hope as many people as possible will have seen it what with the busy festive period.ldquoThe trust isnrsquot supportive of the development. title: there-consequences-leaving-eu-says-ursula-von-der-leyen
story: She told an audience at the London School of Economics, where she formerly studied, that many of the principles of the EU and the single market had been guided by British figures.Ms von der Leyen said January  ndash Britainrsquos exit day ndash would be a ldquotough and emotional day but insisted that theties between the UK and the European Union will continue to be ldquounbreakable even after Brexit.Addressing the crowd she said there would be ldquotough talks ahead between the UK and the EU.She told her audience at the London School of Economics: ldquoYou can choose collaboration over isolation, you can shape your continentrsquos destiny, you can hold your governments accountable, you can refuse to be satisfied with the status quo and can turn things into how they should be.ldquoI know the last few years have been dficult and isive. I hope that by being constructive and ambitious in the upcoming negotiations, we can all move forward together.ldquoThere will be tough talks ahead and each side will do what is best for them.ldquoBut I can assure you that the United Kingdom will always have a trusted friend and partner in the European Union.:MSPs urged to reject Brexit dealShe added: ldquoWhen the sun rises again on February , the United Kingdom and the European Union will still be the best of friends and partners.ldquoThe bonds between us will still be unbreakable."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media bZTeQW poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests bZTeQW.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Ms von der Leyen said there would be ldquoconsequences to leaving the EU and that the UK would have to accept compromises.ldquoOur partnership cannot and will not be the same as before, she said in her speech on Wednesday.ldquoIt will not be as close as before because with every choice comes a consequence. With every decision, comes a trade-off.ldquoWithout the free movement of people, you cannot have the free movement of capital, goods and services.:Boris Johnson renews push to get his Brexit deal through ParliamentldquoWithout a level playing field on environment, labour and state aid, you cannot have the highest quality access to the worldrsquos largest single market.ldquoThe more ergence there is, the more distant the partnership will be.Ms von derLeyen said the EU and Britain would have to prioritise when negotiatingthe Government was not willing to extend the transition period beyond December.ldquoWithout an extension of the transition period beyond , you cannot expect to agree on every single aspect of our new partnership, she warned.ldquoWe will have to prioritise.And she added: ldquoWe are prepared to design a new partnership with zero tarfs, zero quotas, zero dumping ndash a partnership that goes well beyond trade and is unprecedented in scope.

title: alister-jack-confirms-recieved-nicola-sturgeons-request-second-independence-referendum
story: Speaking during Scotland questions, Mr Jack was quick, however, to refute SNP MPrsquos calls for a new vote.Airdrie and Shotts MP Neil Gray questioned the Governmentrsquos decision to refuse the poll.:SNP minister warns against lsquoundemocratic power grabrsquo by WestminsterHe said: ldquoHis party enjoys % of the vote to deliver Brexit and yet denies the SNP its right to give the people of Scotland its say with the % of the vote in Scotland that we have secured.Mr Jack replied: ldquoThe First Minister has asked for the right to set referendums in the future, to decide the context of those.ldquoWe are very clear about this. Constitutional matters are reserved and it would be completely wrong for us to hands those powers over to the Scottish Parliament because we would end up in a series of never-endums.The SNPrsquos deputy Westminster leader Kirsty Blackman accused the Government of ignoring Scottish voters.She said: ldquoThe UK Government has ignored Scottish peoplersquos voices and votes in every election and referendum since , careering on with both Brexit and austerity.:SNP make changes to frontbench team at WestminsterldquoCan the Secretary of State inform us what precise electoral event would convince him that Scotland people should have the right to choose their own future Mr Jack replied: ldquoRegarding whether the time will be right, both Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond at the time said it was a lsquoonce-in-a-generation, once-in-a-letime decisionrsquo.ldquoI donrsquot feel a generation or a letime has passed.Mr Jackrsquos predecessor as Scottish secretary, David Mundell, called on the First Minister to accept the result of the  referendum.Mr Mundell said: ldquoDoes he agree with me though that this document is just another expensive and time-wasting stunt by Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP ldquoThe people of Scotland chose, they chose in  decisively to remain in the UK and itrsquos time Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP accepted that and move on.Mr Jack paid tribute to Mr Mundellrsquos  years as a spokesman on Scottish affairs.He said: ldquoItrsquos quite clear that the Scottish Government constantly harp on about independence and separation because they want to deflect from the main issue and the main issue is that they are failing in our school standards and they are failing our NHS.

title: alister-jack-refuses-handing-power-holyrood-indy-polls-saying-lead-neverendums
story: In a fractious Scottish Questions in the Commons, the Scottish Secretary was bombarded with questions on indyref from the SNP benches.When he took five questions together on the issue of the Scottish Governmentrsquos publication, Scotlandrsquos Right to Choose, Mr Jack quipped to Tory laughter: ldquoTherersquos no independence of thought in the questions.First up, Chris Law, the MP for Dundee West, mocked the Secretary of State, saying he had told Scottish voters repeatedly in the election campaign about how a vote for the Tories would be a vote to stop another independence referendum and noted how that ldquowent well, given the governing party had lost half their Scottish seats and had ldquobarely a rump of MPs.:Alister Jack confirms he has received Nicola Sturgeonrsquos request for a second independence referendumStressing how the SNP had won  per cent of Scottish seats in the December election, Mr Law insisted, to hear-hears from his colleagues, that Scottish voters had, by doing so, expressed their ldquodemocratic will to choose their own future.Mr Jack emphasised how  per cent of Scots voted for the SNP in the election and the same proportion had voted for independence in . To more barracking from the SNP benches, he declared: ldquoThe numbers simply have not changed.ldquoBack in , the independence referendum came on the back of something called the Edinburgh Agreement, which was signed by Alex Salmond and Nicola Sturgeon, the then deputy leader, and in the agreement it said both parties would respect the outcome of the referendum and that hasnrsquot happened.The SNPrsquos Amy Callaghan, the new MP for East Dunbartonshire, accused the Government of a ldquoblinding contradiction ie it claimed to have a mandate to implement Brexit on the back of a  per cent share of the vote but that the Scottish Government did not have one to hold a second referendum on the back of a  per cent share.Mr Jack replied: ldquoIt was a referendum three years ago. We are speaking for the majority of ScotshellipWe are absolutely respecting that decision whereas the SNP are not respecting it and want to tear up the UK.Nationalist MP Neil Gray, who represents Airdrie and Shotts, claimed Mr Jackrsquos performance had demonstrated how untenable the Governmentrsquos position was on indyref, repeating the  per cent  per cent argument.To encouragement from colleagues, he asked: ldquoWhat is his democratic case for denying the people of Scotland their democratic right to choose Mr Jack, who noted how Ms Sturgeonrsquos letter to Boris Johnson of December  would be replied to ldquoin due course, told MPs the FM had asked for the right to set referendums in the future.ldquoWe are very clear about this, he insisted, ldquoconstitutional matters are reserved. It would be completely wrong for us to hand those powers over to the Scottish Parliament because we would end up in a series of neverendums bad for the Scottish, bad for Scottish jobs, reducing tax income and, therefore, damaging already failing public services.One Whitehall source later told The Herald: ldquoIt would be completely irresponsible to hand over the power on referendums as it would paralyse Scotland and Scotlandrsquos economy.In the chamber, Kirsty Blackman, the SNP deputy leader at Westminster, who the party said had taken on the prime constitutional role ldquoin preparation for an independence referendum, claimed the Government had ignored Scottish peoplersquos voices and votes since , ldquocareering on with both Brexit and austerity.She asked Mr Jack what electoral event would convince him that Scotlandrsquos people should have the right to choose their own future.:Relationship between Westminster and Holyrood lsquoat low ebbrsquoThe Scottish Secretary picked up on the austerity issue, saying: ldquoThe Scottish Governmentrsquos own independence figures show there would be a pound.bn hole in the Scottish finances and that would mean real austerity.ldquoRegarding when the time would be right, both Nicola Sturgeon and Alex Salmond said it was a once-in-a-generation, a once-in-a-letime decision. I donrsquot feel a generation or letime have passed.David Mundell, Mr Jackrsquos predecessor at the Scotland Office, said the Scottish Governmentrsquos Right To Choose document was ldquojust another expensive and time-wasting stunt by Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP.He went on: ldquoThe people of Scotland chose in  decisively to remain in the UK and itrsquos time Nicola Sturgeon and the SNP accepted that and moved on.During his tenure at Dover House, the Dumfriesshire MP took Scottish Questions  times.

title: airlines-begin-rerouting-flights-amid-escalating-middle-east-tensions
story: The UK has urged Iran not to carry out further ldquoreckless and dangerous attacks after Tehran fired missiles at military bases in Iraq hosting British and US troops.British Airways rerouted flight  from Mumbai to Heathrow mid-way through the flight, to avoid crossing Iraqi airspace. The plane flew in a circle and was then erted to the Greek capital Athens for refuelling.:Trump knows Iran weakness will hamper re-election oddsThe move has left a number of Indian passport holders stuck in the terminal as they do not possess the right visa to leave the airport.One passenger, who asked not to be named, told the PA news agency that Indian nationals had been stuck in the terminal for a number of hours.He said: ldquoSince we donrsquot have Schengen visa, BA couldnrsquot put us in hotels which are outside the airport. Athens staff are doing their best to find alternate BA flights for us but looks like  odd passengers couldnrsquot be accommodated.ldquoSo either we will be put on other flights or  have to spend the night at the terminal lounge.He said the flight, which took off more than  hours ago, had been rescheduled to Thursday morning.British Airways said: ldquoWe appreciate the frustrating situation that a handful of our customers are in, without visas to enter Greece, following the ersion.ldquoWe have apologised to our customers for the delay to their travel plans and our colleagues are doing everything they can to rebook customers, and take care of them until their flight departs.Virgin Atlantic said it is ldquoclosely monitoring the situation and its aircraft are not flying over Iranian airspace. Due to changes in flight routing, trips to and from Mumbai may take longer than expected.Australian carrier Qantas said it is altering its route from London to Perth, Australia, to avoid Iranian and Iraqi airspace until further notice.Malaysia Airlines and Singapore Airlines have also rerouted planes to avoid Iranian airspace.The US Federal Aviation Administration has barred American pilots and carriers from flying in areas of Iraqi, Iranian and some Persian Gulf airspace while the Russian aviation agency has recommended all Russian airlines avoid flying over Iran, Iraq, the Persian Gulf and the Gulf of Oman.:Iran launches missiles at US bases in IraqForeign Secretary Dominic Raab has urged Iran to pursue ldquourgent de-escalation as the crisis in the Gulf intensies.US President Donald Trump tweeted ldquoall is well following the attack on the bases, which was carried out in response to the killing of Iranian General Qassem Soleimani by America.US officials said  missiles were fired, with  striking the Ain al-Asad base  miles west of Baghdad, one striking a base in Irbil in northern Iraqrsquos semi-autonomous Kurdish region, and another four missing their targets.

title: scots-tory-hopeful-defends-comments
story: Michelle Ballantyne said in  ldquopeople on benefit cannot have as many children as they like while people ldquowho work and pay their way considered the size of their families.The South of Scotland MSP, who is challenging favourite Jackson Carlaw for the Scottish Tory leadership, yesterday defended her position, but toned down her language.She told BBC Radio Scotland that ldquopeople can have as many children as they like, but should also consider family income.She said: ldquoWhat I said is that we need a level playing field. So people who are in work need to have the same opportunities as people who arenrsquot in work.ldquoYou canrsquot go to your employer and say lsquoIrsquove just decided to have another baby so could I have a pay rise pleasersquo. So this is about fairness.Ms Ballantyne, her partyrsquos social security spokeswoman at Holyrood, was an early supporter of Brexit and Mr Johnson, while Mr Carlaw was a late convert to both.Nominations close on January  and the winner is revealed on February .SNP MSP Christine Grahame said: ldquoThe ugly reality of the Tories in Scotland has been exposed ndash with both would-be leaders shown to be mired in controversy, offering a home to prejudiced views, and doubling down on offensive statements.ldquoWhile Jackson Carlaw has been an enthusiastic cheerleader for Boris Johnsonrsquos extreme Brexit and the very worst Tory policies, Michelle Ballantyne has consistently shown a chilling indference to those in need - shedding light on the true character of the Tory party.

title: funding boost for inverurie men s shed
story: Inverurie  District Men#s Shed has become the latest beneficiary of the Barratt Homes North Scotland Community Fund giveaway.The group will be using its £, windfall from the housebuilder to help fund the regeneration of a leased field, allowing the group to build a new polytunnel for growing fruits and vegetables.Inverurie  District Men’s Shed is one of more than  Men’s Sheds in Scotland and all have been created with the aim of improving members’ wellbeing, social interaction and co-operation.More than  members are part of Inverurie  District Men’s Shed – located at Harlaw Industrial Estate – and many work on their own skills-based projects, including building wooden planters, repairing household items, making benches or crafting seasonal themed items.The new field was recently offered to the group by a generous local landowner and is expected to provide the Men’s Shed with enough space to create allotments to grow their own produce and build and maintain gardening skills.Archie Peebles from Inverurie District Men’s Shed, said: “Our group is only able to exist thanks to the generosity of local iniduals and businesses like Barratt Homes. Local support means everything to us and we’re incredibly thankful for this £, gt.”David Palmer, Managing Director for Barratt North Scotland, said: “Improving and maintaining positive wellbeing during our daily lives is crucial. Men’s Shed’s across the country do a fantastic job of getting people involved, reducing loneliness and helping create better, more circular communities.“We look forward to helping them where we can in the future.”data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The children at Rothienorman School enjoyed the visit from the SSEN Transmission team"  SSEN talk to bright spark pupils viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: mackie s launches world s first haggis neeps and tatties crisps
story: Haggis, neeps and tatties will be available in potato crisp form this month thanks to Mackies Crisps.Due to hit the shelves from early January, Mackie’s Crisps has taken inspiration from the Bard himself, Robert Burns, and is bringing consumers a snack-based taste of Scotland’s favourite traditional dish in the run-up to Burns Night.A limited run of , g bags will be available with a comforting, light peppery flavour and Taylor-clan tartan packaging.Using entirely natural flavourings and high oleic sunflower oil, the crisps are suitable for both vegans and vegetarians.James Taylor, from the Perthshire-based family business, is delighted with the flavour and hopes it resonates with the Scottish public.He said: “While we do push the boat out with exotic flavours, we do also like to look closer to home at some of the fantastic dishes from our heritage. Quite simply, there are none more iconic than our own national dish.“We’re fiercely proud of our Scottish roots and so narrowed down to a number of options for a limited run. When it came to the taste tests, haggis, neeps and tatties emerged as the runaway favourite.”James is the fourth generation to work at the Taylor farm – and is Commercial Director at Mackie’s at Taypack, which produces Mackie’s Crisps. He helps to run the family-owned business with his father, Managing Director George Taylor.The crisps brand and Mackie’s at Taypack as a business were launched in  as the result of a joint-venture between potato farmers the Taylor family and Aberdeenshire’s Mackie’s of Scotland, which is renowned for its ice cream and chocolate.Its thick-cut and gently cooked potato crisps use the best ieties of crisping potatoes, grown on the farm, reflective of its “plough to pack” ethos.Subsequently, Mackie’s Crisps has become famous for its haggis and cracked black pepper iety, as well as launching the world’s first pigs in blankets flavour.Research on its new flavour started in earnest in  during a new product development push, after establishing Burns Night as an opening to deliver a new patriotic flavour combination.Meticulous sampling sessions helped it to master the flavour of haggis, neeps and tatties, building on its popular haggis-based flavours.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Members of Inverurie  District Mens Shed accept the donation from Barratt Homes"  Funding boost for Inverurie Men’s Shed viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"The Mackie’s Crisps team were further convinced of launching the flavour when a student, Aileen McColm, joined the Perthshire business in  to shadow quality control manager Jamie McKell. She undertook a survey, with  respondents showing the flavour to be the favoured option for the target market. James added: “It’s been many years in the making, so we’ll be keeping in contact with our end customers and trade clients throughout to see what the appetite is like for our new flavour.“Who knows, we may even be able to expand the run to make it a permanent addition to our range. We’d also love to be able to sell bags abroad, helping the wider world to experience the taste of haggis, neeps and tatties.”

title: ssen talk to bright spark pupils
story: SSEN Transmission staff visited Rothienorman School last month to talk to the children about how energy works and how they can stay road safe during construction.The staff are currently working on the construction of the Rothienorman substation, which forms part of SSEN Transmission’s reinforcement and improvement of the transmission network in the North East and East Coast of Scotland.The school visit marked a busy couple of weeks for the team, following visits to the substation site by members of the local community, Fisherford Community Council and Rothienorman Community Association.During their visit they talked to the pupils about the key role Rothienorman substation will play in facilitating the connection of renewable energy to the National Grid on the North East Coast.They also showed them how the substation will help control the flow of energy across the north east, directing renewable energy generated around Peterhead, and assist with the delivery of energy to where it’s needed, while highlighting the key role SSEN Transmission plays in supporting the transition to Net Zero.Finally they used their visit to talk about staying safe around increased local and construction traffic and gave each pupil a high visibility vest and snap band to wear when travelling to and from school on dark mornings and winter nights, helping the children to “think bright” about road safety and improve their visibility to drivers on the road.Following the visit Gary Donlin, SSEN Transmission’s Community Liaison Manager, commented: “We really enjoyed our visit to Rothienorman School.“It was great to see the children so interested in finding out how energy works and the role SSEN Transmission plays in facilitating renewable generation and the transition to Net Zero.”Mr Donlin added: “We have been working closely with community since the early development of the project and this has continued into construction, it is important to us to ensure we work together to actively mitigate any impacts of the works.“We were pleased we were able to talk about keeping road safe around construction traffic and give the children high-vis to help themselves to be seen by drivers during the dark mornings and nights.”Work on the substation began in April this year and is expected to be completed in summer .data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch title: top trade at thainstone sale
story: Trade reached a top of # at Aberdeen and Northern Marts# th anniversary show and sale of store cattle on Friday, January .Sale leader on the day was a -month-old British Blue cross heer from brothers William and David Moir of Moir Livestock, Newmill of Rathen, Fraserburgh, who sold  heers to average p per kg.Weighing kg, their sale topper was an unshown heer bred by A MacDonald, The Ess, Carrbridge, which sold to Gordon Cameron, Newton Cottage, Acharacle, Argyll.Two other Limousin cross heers from Moir Livestock made £, apiece when sold to Gary Bell, Haaside, Lockerbie, while another sold for £, to A and E Neachell and Son, Shrubbery Farm, Aldridge, Staffordshire.The champion in the pre-sale show, sponsored by Thomson of Sauchen, was awarded to a -month-old Limousin cross heer from Steven Smith, The Byre, Sunnyhill Croft, Turrf.Tapped out by judges Gavin and Stuart Ross, Wardhead, Strichen, was a kg heer bred by George Jack, Woodend, Killearnan, Muir of Ord, which later sold for £, to J Gordon and Co, Waterside of Forbes, Alford.The reserve honours went to a -month-old Charolais cross heer weighing kg from Moir Livestock.This was a heer bred by A Smith, The Leys, Tarland, Aboyne, which made £, when purchased by Mark Baxter, The Bungalow, Troup Home Farm, Gamrie, Banff.AC Fotheringham, Ballinloan, Dunkeld, Perth, stood champion in the home-bred section with a -month-old Limousin cross heer. Weighing kg, she sold for £ to Walter Dandie and Sons, Learielaw, Broxburn.Meanwhile, proceeds from a -month-old Charolais cross heer from Malcolm Allan, Uppermill Farms, Kintore, were donated to north-east cancer charity Friends of Anchor. She sold for £, to judge Gavin Ross, Wardhead, Strichen.Commenting on the sale afterwards Aberdeen and Northern Marts’ head of livestock John Angus, said: “Our th anniversary show and sale attracted a tremendous show of stock which sold to a packed ringside of active buyers, with trade surpassing sellers’ expectations.”For more information about Aberdeen and Northern Marts or the ANM Group go online to www.anmarts.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The haggis, neeps and tatties crisps"  Mackie’s launches world’s first haggis, neeps and tatties crisps viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "INVE | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "INVE | Article Teaser"

title: calls for urgent review of ambulance cover in orkney
story: newsCalls for urgent review of ambulance cover in OrkneyJanuary ,  at : am vw, px"  Orkney MSP Liam McArthurOrkney’s MSP, Liam McArthur, is calling for an urgent review into ambulance cover in Orkney.Last month, Mr McArthur raised with ministers concerns that emergency calls risked being left waiting while Orkney’s only land ambulance was responding to another call.He also askedOrkney had been left without land ambulance cover for a period of time over the past year.In response, the minister for public health, Joe Fitzpatrick, has written to Mr McArthur confirming that there were  occasions between December , , and December ,  when emergency calls in Orkney were left waiting due to the ambulance responding to another call.There was also an occasion when Orkney was left without any ambulance cover on the mainland and linked south isles for two hours.Commenting on the minister’s response, Mr McArthur said: “These figures reveal the extent to which land ambulance capacity in Orkney is failing to meet the needs of patients. People in Orkney will be shocked to hear how often those making emergency calls are being forced to wait due to a lack of land ambulance cover. In many instances, these will be cases where the response time can be critical.“This is absolutely no criticism of Orkney’s ambulance crews, who do outstanding work in operating a service that is clearly over-stretched. Indeed, the admission from the Minister about the scale of the problem shows that local crews are being let down by a lack of resources and support. This can only be making an already dficult job even more challenging.“I am due to meet senior representatives of the Scottish Ambulance Service early next month. I will make clear the need for an urgent review into the resources available locally and calling for additional capacity to meet the needs of the Orkney community. This is the very least that the public and our ambulance staff deserve.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: council seek your views on quanterness wind farm
story: Feedback is being invited into a major development which would see a six-turbine wind farm be constructed on the outskirts of Kirkwall.Orkney Islands Council, as part of their community wind farm project, intend to submit a planning application for six turbines at Quanterness, St Ola, in early .The development is set to consist of six turbines with a maximum blade-tip height of .-metres and associated infrastructure such as hardstandings, access tracks, a met mast and a substation compound.Public exhibitions unveiling the project, which would also see turbines placed in Faray and Hoy, were held in November.In December, councillors voted that applications pertaining to the project be taken over by the Scottish Government rather than be solely decided at local level here in Orkney.Now, with the proposals classed as a “major development” there is a requirement for the council to carry out a pre-application consultation.This consultation is used to inform communities about major and national development proposals and to have an opportunity to contribute views before a formal planning application is submitted.The deadline for submitting comments and views to the project team has been extended to pm on Friday, January , and feedback forms can be found on the council website here.Alternatively, feedback can be provided by phone on .copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: freight ship to be back on pentland firth route
story: NorthLink Ferries has confirmed that the freight ship Helliar is to operate on the Pentland Firth route while the Hamnavoe is away in drydock from next week.The Hamnavoe is due to be in drydock from this coming Monday, January , until Sunday January .The company says that there will be additional north and southbound calls into Kirkwall by the Hrossey and Hjaltland during this time.A NorthLink spokesperson added: #The Hamnavoe, which operates between Scrabster and Stromness will have “Changing Places” installed during the upcoming dry dock period. These fully accessible facilities have an adult-sized, height adjustable changing bench, a hoist and a centrally placed toilet. NorthLink have worked closely with the Scottish charity PAMIS to ensure these are to specication and are delighted to be the first ferry operator to have these toilets on all passenger vessels.#Giving further details of the work due to be undertaken, they added: #The availability of an external power supply, a shore supply, will be utilised to complete the final vessel commissioning of the onboard modications to the vessel’s electrical switchboard to accept shore power.#Various mechanical works will be undertaken, including major services on the port main engine, starboard main engine and the port gearbox. All works are planned maintenance tasks complying with the manufacturer’s recommended service schedules and overseen by the manufacturer’s approved service engineers.#Drydock maintenance will also be completed on propellers, shaft lines and stabilisers along with statutory out of water surveys and inspections by the Classication Society and Flag Administration.#The company, who have in the past been criticised for putting the freight ship on the route, further stated that the scheduled drydock period has been designed to minimise disruption to customers, and takes place during the quietest time of year for both passenger and freight shipments.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. story: newsKirkwall THI works to continue from MondayJanuary ,  at : am vw, px"  The final phase of works, being carried out as part of the Kirkwall THI project, will re-start from Monday.This final phase of the project will see the closure of the section of street outside the Royal Bank of Scotland and at the junction with Victoria Street and Tankerness Lane.This means that Tankerness Lane and Victoria Street will be closed to vehicles while pedestrian access will be maintained.Broad Street and Palace Road will be open to traffic during this time and access to the southern end of Victoria Street will remain open for cars and light goods vehicles via Victoria Road.The council has said work should be completed by early February . However, the road will remain closed for a further three weeks to ensure the construction materials have set.During this time residents and businesses should continue to put out their waste bins as normal at am on waste collection days. title: one win apiece as stromness yule log contests end 2019 on a high
story: The weather gods shined on Stromness as the town celebrated the final day of  with the now annual Yule Log contests.A huge crowd flocked to the town to witness the Northenders win their first Yule Log battle since its revival in , winning the junior spectacle.Beginning outside the Pier Arts Centre, the Soothenders put up stf resistance yet there was simply no stopping a determined and vocal north side.Both the junior and senior battles were over in a matter of minutes, however, that failed to dampen the enthusiasm and spirit around the town.The senior contest begun outside the Commercial Hotel and for the opening minutes, it appeared asthe much smaller team of the north would turn the contest their way, inching the -kilogram log back towards their goal of the Pierhead.The town#s chinese takeaway shop would be as far as they got however.The Soothenders reorganised themselves and turned the tide. Once they gained the momentum, there was simply no stopping the south from winning a third straight contest.The log was hauled through the street, dragging several Northenders off their feet, and victory was secured when the log reached the Red Cross Shop.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: uppie men seal a double win for new year 2020
story: After a game lasting a little over six hours, the Uppies have emerged as the victories team in the  Men#s New Years Day Ba#, with Magnus Baillie, from Toab, raised high from their ranks as the overall winner.This sealed a double-header from the Uppies as we head into a new decade, with the team and Ewan Stevenson also taking the victory in the boys# game earlier today.In a game that did feature breaks but was won through solid pushing power, every metre gained was hard-earned. Following the throw from former Doonie player Barrie Reid at pm, the game travelled as close to the Shorie goal as the back of the Kirkwall iCentre before a break involving Mr Baillie#s son Findley Cooper saw the beginning of a slow journey up Great Western Road toward Lidl supermarket and then onto Junction Road.With both teams seeming to get the upper hand at dferent times, it was hard to tell what the outcome would be. However, on this occasion, the Uppies weren#t to be resisted and they eventually claimed a very hard-fought win.With the Doonies fighting to the last minute, a mighty throw saw the ba#, made by Edgar Gibson, hit Mackinson#s Corner, and within just a few minutes Mr Baillie emerged from the pack as the winner, to cheers and singing from his teammates.Asked to described how he felt about the win, he replied: #I#m absolutely over the moon. You have no idea how much this means to me. I don#t know what time the game finished, it must have been six or seven hours, but what a team game.#copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: fa-urged-reconsider-deal-betting-firm
story: Reiss Nelson scores for Arsenal in their FA Cup rd round match against Leeds UtdCulture Secretary Nicky Morgan has said she hopes the Football Association will ldquoreconsider after it allowed a betting company to broadcast FA Cup matches.It comes more than two years after the governing body said it would end partnerships with gambling firms.Bet, which allows football fans to watch playthey place a bet via their app, has been showing matches since the start of last season.The partnership drew criticism from viewers and campaigners over the weekend when all matches were delayed by a minute to promote the Duke of Cambridgersquos mental health charity.Ms Morgan tweeted: ldquoThis is a contractual matter for the FA  Bet but things have moved on since the contract was signed  I hope they will re-consider.This is a contractual matter for the FA  Bet but things have moved on since the contract was signed  I hope they will re-consider https:t.co KJAoLDiUmdash Nicky MorganJanuary , The FA announced in July  that it would no longer have a betting partner after terminating a contract with Ladbrokes.A spokesman said the FA would review the arrangements of its deal with IMG, the third party that sold the rights to Bet, when the contract expires after the end of next season.It stressed that the deal with IMG was a pre-existing broadcast deal done before it made its decision in mid- to end its official betting partnership with Ladbrokes.The FA said: ldquoThe FA agreed a media rights deal with IMG in early , part of which permits them to sell the right to show live footage or clips of FA Cup matches to bookmakers. Bet acquired these rights from IMG to use from the start of the - season.ldquoThis deal was agreed before we made a clear decision on the FArsquos relationship with gambling companies in June  when we ended our partnership with Ladbrokes.ldquoWe will review this element of the media rights sales process ahead of tendering rights to the new cycle from the - season onwards. Leagues and clubs continue to govern their own relationships with gambling companies. Bet said in a statement: ldquoBet does not sponsor the FA or the FA Cup and does not have any direct commercial agreement with the FA. bet, along with multiple other operators, has the right to live stream certain FA Cup matches through a long standing media rights deal with IMG.ldquoThere is no obligation on betrsquos customers to place a bet on any FA Cup match to enjoy the live streams at bet.To do so, customers are simply required to either have a funded bet account or to have placed a bet on any event with bet in the previous  hours. This requirement importantly ensures that all such customers are fully veried to prevent under s from accessing the service.ldquoBet believes that these streaming services provide added value to its customers and enable them to watch FA Cup matches that they might not otherwise have been able to see.Last weekendrsquos third-round matches all signposted the Heads Up campaign, a joint initiative between the FA and the charity Heads Together, spearheaded by William.All fixtures other than the  that kicked off at .pm on Saturday were screened live by Bet, including Liverpoolrsquos derby against Everton and Arsenal versus Leeds.National mental health director for the NHS Claire Murdoch said: ldquoBet to view is simply wrong and needs to stop. Football needs to rethink its relationship with the betting industry and reconsider gamblingrsquos role in the beautul game.ldquoThis is another own-goal from the gambling industry.ldquoBetting firms talk a good game when it comes to tackling addiction but it is no wonder that ndash with tactics like these ndash more people are seeking help for gambling problems on the NHS.ldquoThe NHS never stands still as health needs change, which is why wersquore rolling out new specialist services to tackle mental ill-health linked to gambling addiction, as part of our Long Term Plan, but it is high time that all these firms who spend many millions on marketing and advertising step up to the plate and take their responsibilities seriously.The Royal Society for Public Healthsaid the deal ldquodemonstrates the need for a complete overhaul of regulation around sports and gambling.Chief executive Shirley Cramer said: ldquoThis is a rotten deal from start to finish, and it is extremely disappointing that the FA has been such a willing participant in the gamblication of football. Football has played an historic role in unying our society, yet problem gambling and gambling disorder can tear families and communities apart, and has led to the loss of far too many lives already.ldquoThe reality is that lives are at risk now and waiting until  is not good enough ndash urgent action is needed to prevent further harm and the FA must work to scrap this harmful deal without delay. The Bishop of St Albans, Dr Alan Smith, described the situation as ldquoextraordinary.He said: ldquoThis plan puts gambling at the very core of broadcast football and may be unilaterally breaking gambling firmsrsquo ad ban ndash made only last year.ldquoItrsquos extraordinary that football bosses are allowing bookies to carry out this wholesale lsquogamblicationrsquo of our national sport. Football bosses will have to explain themselves, not least to parents and young people.ldquoAdvertising and promoting gambling is widely understood to be linked with levels of gambling-related harm which are damaging public health at unprecedented levels. Promoting this harm must not be the fate for the national, beautul game.ldquoYet it is only through paper-thin regulation that this happened. The regulators have said they would stand against this direction of travel, so they too must provide an explanation.Malcolm Clarke, chairman of The Football Supportersrsquo Association, said: ldquoThis deal highlights the major concerns fans have about the growth of gambling in football ndash governing bodies need to take these concerns seriously.ldquoThrough our partnership with GambleAware, we are taking real steps to promote safer gambling in football and we call on the FA to get around the table on the issue. There is much more to be done to protect fans from the risks of gambling.In December it was revealed that Bet chief executive Denise Coates had kept her place as the highest-paid boss in the country after pocketing a pound million basic pay rise last year and taking home abasic salary of almost pound million in the year ended March .It comes on top of the around pound million she is believed to have received in idends as a major shareholder.copy -. story: Nurse strikeThe head of the South Eastern Health Trust has called for a resurrection of Stormont to tackle demands for pay parity.Seamus McGoran was speaking as thousands of nurses took part in their second day of strikes over pay and staffing levels.He told the PA news agency that outpatient appointments and  procedures had been cancelled across trust sites, which include the Ulster and Lagan Valley Hospitals.The senior official added the true impact is higher, revealing there are usually , outpatient appointments on a typical Wednesday but they stopped booking slots when they learned of the planned industrial action. ldquoThere is quite a signicant impact across our hospital services. There will be further impact with cancellations on Friday, albeit to a lesser extent,  outpatients and  procedures ndash but I donrsquot underestimate on an inidual personal level what that means for all of those people, he said.Mr McGoran said he is content the trust has ldquomanaged things as best we can on a dficult day.ldquoBut we are feeling real pressure now at the Ulster Hospital emergency department as we expected, he said.Mr McGoran said he wanted to make it clear on behalf of the chief executives of all the health trusts in Northern Ireland that they support their staff and what he termed ldquotheir legitimate claim for pay parity with their colleagues in England.ldquoThey are incredible people, they do a fantastic job for our patients and we believe they should be rewarded in the same way as colleagues are in other parts of the UK, he said.ldquoWe obviously recognise the authority is not within the gt of our department of health and we are very clear that we need a political solution to actually deal with this as a matter of urgency.ldquoWe are really, really hoping that our politicians can get their act together and find an agreement to get back into an executive before January .ldquoThatrsquos really where we need to see a solution.Mr McGoran said the health service needs political leadership.ldquoI think when it comes to staffing levels for our services, ourselves, our staff, our trade union colleagues, wersquore all on the same page with this, we all recognise the huge, ever-increasing demand on our services and all want to build our staffing levels up to the point where we have absolute ability to meet all of the needs of our patients, he said.ldquoWersquore having to prioritise our most urgent patients and, for example, those who are waiting for planned care, those numbers are getting bigger and the s of waits is getting longer, so we really need political leadership.ldquoWe need long-term investment and we need a workforce plan that will deliver more sustainable staffing levels for many years to come.copy -. title: new-licensing-schemes-airbnb-style-lets-scotland-announced
story: Campaigners against Airbnb-style letsAirbnb-style short-term lets could be subject to new licensing schemes from spring next year, the Scottish Government has announced.Housing Minister Kevin Stewart also revealed the Scottish Government will ldquocarefully and urgently consider the way they are taxed.As well as handing councils the power to bring in licensing schemes, local authorities will in future be able to designate new control areas for short-term lets, with those wanting to let out properties in this way first having to obtain planning permission.#Councils are to be given new powers to regulate short-term lets in their local community. Find out more about the new licencing scheme, which includes mandatory safety controls ## https:t.co QgKBzGv pic AxpiOXHmdash Scot Gov FairerJanuary , The measures are being introduced following concerns about the impact such lets have on areas such as Edinburgh ndash one of the most popular places for Airbnb listings.Just over halfof all Airbnb properties in Scotland are either located in the city or the Highlands.Announcing the changes, Mr Stewart said: ldquoIbelieve that these measures allow us to make progress in this Parliament to address a pressing issue for some of our communities but they will not unduly curtail the many benefits of short-term lets to hosts, visitors and the Scottish economy.The Scottish Government will monitor the impact of the moves, with Mr Stewart saying he could come back with legislationproblems persist.Hesaid: ldquoShort-term lets can offer people a flexible travel option and have contributed positively to Scotlandrsquos tourism industry and local economies across the country.ldquoHowever, we know that in certain areas, particularly tourist hot spots, high numbers of short-term lets are causing problems and often make it harder for people to find homes to live in.ldquoThat is why we are empowering local authorities to implement a system that works for their area.ldquoBy giving councils the power to set conditions around short-term lets licences and put in place planning control areas to tackle hot spots, communities across Scotland will be able to decide what is best for them and their local economy.We have been calling for three things to stop holiday lets destroying our communities: new taxes, landlord registration, and limits on the number of holiday lets. Today the Scottish Government has announced actions on all of these: https:t.co RnciwIHimdash Living RentJanuary , Mr Stewart added: ldquoEverybody wants visitors, hosts, neighbours and local residents to be safe.ldquoThat is why the licensing scheme includes a safety element which will be mandatory across Scotland for all short-term lets.Edinburgh City Council leader Adam McVey said the changes were ldquoextremely welcome news and would ldquogive us the controls that we need over short-term lets for our residents and communities across Edinburgh.He said: ldquoTodayrsquos announcement by the minister meets our request for mandatory licences and we will now be in a position to more effectively implement planning controls to stop the increase of short-term lets.ldquoA review of taxation of short-term lets will also make sure that businesses are paying properly for income theyrsquore receiving and local services theyrsquore using.He added: ldquoWersquoll now work with the Scottish Government on the details of the new system, which I hope will allow us to react quickly when rules are breached as well as addressing the particular challenges we face in Edinburgh, such as housing being taken out of supply, rising rents and antisocial behaviour. --Green MSP Andy Wightmancommended the moves by the Scottish Government--Andy Wightman, the Green MSP for the Lothians, who has campaigned for better regulation of short-term lets, said he was pleased ministers had acted.He added: ldquoThose communities who have been adversely impacted by short-term lets will be pleased that the Government has now committed to introducing a much-needed, long overdue licensing scheme by .But the Scottish Conservatives were cautious, saying: ldquoRegulation is necessary but there are next to no details on how this might work.ldquoFor example, we donrsquot even knowcouncils will be able to refuse licences or on what grounds.ldquoThere is a danger that we could have a triple tax whammy on tourismthe SNP introduces an Airbnb tax on top of a tourist tax and a fee for licences.Housing campaigners said the changes were a ldquowelcome first step.Graeme Brown, the director of homeless charity Shelter Scotland, said the ldquounregulated growth of short-term lets ldquohas led to too many people being locked out of homes that could be let privately to help tackle Scotlandrsquos housing emergency.Megan Bishop from Living Rent, Scotlandrsquos tenantsrsquo union, hailed the announcement as a ldquohuge step forward for tenants in Scotland.copy -.
